body: Having this issue too

This seems to be caused by
https://github.com/vsls-contrib/chat/blob/master/src/discord/index.ts#L118
```js
  async validateToken(): Promise<CurrentUser | undefined> {
``` 
sending the incorrect Authorization header

Check: https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#authentication

After forcing the token type to be "Bot" I was able to login with a bot token, however new messages weren't being displayed
Is there any plan to fix this?

Thanks for taking the time to report this @ghazpar. The Live Share integration for chat definitely emerged as a key scenario for this extension (which focuses on just chat), and we have aligned on a path where chat becomes a first class feature of Live Share core. You will see activity on moving chat into the Live Share extension, which would fix these coordination issues between the two extensions.

Thanks for the quick response. So @arjun27, are you saying that these issues are known, but can't be fixed without integration into the live share core? Any idea about a timeframe for that? Or are you saying that these issues stem from the live share extension itself? In which case I should make a bug report there?

Tested for MacOS Catalina 10.15.3 using VS Code 1.43.1 with Live Share Pack 0.3.4, Live Share Chat 0.33.0, Live Share Audio 0.1.80, Live Share Extension Pack 0.3.4.

I can confirm for the Microphone Permission, MacOS doesn't trigger the permission for Electron/VS Code and one doesn't not simply give permission manually on a MacOS.

I don't have the knowledge to propose a fix, but apparently for Electron there's a way to get the media access status and/or request it, it's necessary since Mojave 10.14
[Electron Ask For Media Access](https://www.electronjs.org/docs/api/system-preferences#systempreferencesaskformediaaccessmediatype-macos)
Chat is now integrated in the core Live Share extension. Please file an issue if you are running into issues with the Slack integration.

Thanks @James-revans and @KarmicXKoala for reporting this. I'm trying to debug, but unable to repro. My best guess is that you are facing [authorization issues](https://github.com/vsls-contrib/chat/blob/master/docs/SLACK.md#admin-approval-required) on the selected workspace

To help me debug this better, can you run the "Toggle developer tools" command in VS Code? That should give us some helpful logs.

Even outside of the Slack auth process, there seems to be something broken with DNS for the hosted oauth lambda service (https://github.com/vsls-contrib/chat/tree/master/oauth-service).

It claims to be set up on https://vscode.chat, but I can't find any name server that will resolve that domain. Who's controlling `vscode.chat` and its configuration?

Google Public DNS:
```
➜ nslookup vscode.chat 8.8.8.8
Server:		8.8.8.8
Address:	8.8.8.8#53

** server can't find vscode.chat: SERVFAIL
```

The `.chat` name servers:
```
➜ nslookup vscode.chat DEMAND.ALPHA.ARIDNS.NET.AU
Server:		DEMAND.ALPHA.ARIDNS.NET.AU
Address:	2001:dcd:1::7#53

Non-authoritative answer:
*** Can't find vscode.chat: No answer
```

The AWS DNS provided on the whois record for `vscode.chat`:
```
➜ nslookup vscode.chat ns-1800.awsdns-33.co.uk
Server:		ns-1800.awsdns-33.co.uk
Address:	2600:9000:5307:800::1#53

** server can't find vscode.chat: REFUSED
```
yeah `vscode.chat` seems to not be existing online anymore?

Yeah, that is how I was thinking. Currently, the extension maintains state about chat (Slack) workspaces in `localStorage`. This can be matched against repo-level settings, which could define something like

```
chat.enabledWorkspaces: {
   type: "slack",
   id: "workspace-id"
}
```

The Slack app does not access anything from inside VS Code. Let me lay down how the various pieces work to detail this out:

1/ The Team Chat extension is a VS Code extension that uses VS Code APIs - like to create a web view, show unread count in the status bar item. The extension can access VS Code content, since there are APIs for that. The extension is also fully open source, so you can see what API calls are being used.

2/ The extension works with multiple chat providers: Slack, Discord and VS Live Share. The extension uses APIs provided by these chat providers, and in the case of Slack, the extension uses authentication provided by the "Slack App" primitive. These API calls include sending/receiving messages, fetching unread counts, etc.

3/ The chat providers cannot access VS Code APIs directly, and are disconnected from the content inside the editor. In the future, we do want to make it easier for you to share things like "code snippets" in your chat thread - but these implementations will be sent as messages that are explicitly sent by the user over a chat provider API.

Hope this answers the question. Feel free to re-open if there's any other question

Thanks for reporting @aejay-rs. I want to get to the bottom of this and fix it. The extension is not expected to change the presence status on its own - only running the "Change presence status" command explicitly is expected to change it. I can review the code to ensure this behavior.

From your experience, does it look like the presence is changing in the background, without any user action?
I had the same problem and have disabled this extension for now.

Yeah--I had never called that command outright. I didn't realize it was even an available command until I was peeking around the source code a bit yesterday. I also got the impression that presence was only intended to be updated via that command, but I didn't know if perhaps I was just overlooking something, since I'm not very familiar with building VS Code extensions.

It's still early to be definite, but yesterday morning I disabled the extension and revoked the authorization in Slack for my own account, and I haven't seen the issue occur since then. I'm led to believe that this extension is involved but I'm not sure how or why just yet.

Thanks! The presence API docs talk about an "automatic away" [feature](https://api.slack.com/docs/presence-and-status#user-presence), which might be causing this issue. I'll investigate on how it "detects activity in the client".

> The Slack message servers will automatically detect activity in the client. After 30 minutes with no activity, the user is automatically marked as away. There is some additional nuance to that dependent on the client, explained in detail in our Help Center.

fyi - I've verified that the `users.setPresence` API call is not being made from our code, unless there's an explicit user action. I'm on an email thread with the Slack developer support team to figure out how "automatic away" works and whether we can turn that off. My theory is that the RTM connection is idle, causing the "automatic away" to get triggered

Huh, yeah, that would be unexpected. If it turns out that's how the auto-away functions, they should really consider updating their API docs to make that clear. I'm sure this wouldn't be the first implementation to trip up on that.

I am having this issue as well and can confirm it is related to this extension. When I open up slack channel in VS Code using this extension my status is immediately set back to available.

Thanks for reporting this @The-New-Guy. Quick status update: the Slack support team is running tests to check if automatic away is behaving correctly. Once they share results, I will make any relevant changes at my end.

I'm eager to fix this - thanks for the patience!

Thanks for reporting this @flagrama, and adding more details with the edits, helpful stuff. Let me first talk about existing muted channels, and then cover the need to mute additional channels (ones that are not relevant for development).

I was going to write that there is a bug in how we handle muted channels in Discord -- as detailed in the code below:

https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/blob/ec023f1ffd865f8328bb98c55c0fc256dff13377/src/extension.ts#L94-L99

This relies on the `muted` flag, but from your edits it appears like the flag does not work in upstream. I'll investigate why this is the case -- at the very least we should be able to replicate the notification preferences from Discord by default, so that muted channels on Discord are automatically muted in the extension.

On muting additional channels: I agree we need a way to do that as well, especially since more and more users are using the extension to not get distracted by chat - and have dev related chat channels for easy access. We could have an additional config for this which is restricted to the extension.

I'm going to prioritize fixing the former issue first, and then get to the second. Hope that works for you.

Hey @arjun27 there's no need to look for a better way to store creds.

VS Code uses Node's `keytar` package to access the key store on various platforms. 

Per the [documentation](https://www.npmjs.com/package/keytar) This issue can be resolved by installing `libsecret-1-dev`:

**Debian/Ubuntu:** `sudo apt-get install libsecret-1-dev`
**Red Hat-based:** `sudo yum install libsecret-devel`
**Arch Linux:** `sudo pacman -S libsecret`

@arjun27 Hello,

I'm working on Mattermost provider, and Mattermost is self-hosted service that could be multiple host + teams.

Is this includes supporting multiple hosts? or just only workspace?

thanks @cometkim. Going by the definitions in the [mattermost docs](https://docs.mattermost.com/help/getting-started/welcome-to-mattermost.html?highlight=workspace), this PR is relevant for teams (workspaces), not hosts. This is a change internal to a provider: the Discord provider has always supported multiple workspaces, but this change brings that to Slack. The distinction is that the Discord uses one auth token for multiple workspaces, but Slack has different tokens for different workspaces. This meant the token handling had to become provider/workspace specific -- which is the change in this PR.

Discord/Slack don't need multiple hosts support, so we don't have any building blocks for hosts as of now. Happy to discuss this in more detail and come to a solution that would work for you.

thanks @temitope. are you running into `access_denied` errors with the other slack groups (workspaces)?

Ah, got it. This typically happens when the workspace restricts app installations to admins only. Most slack apps are like bots, meaning once an admin installs the app, the app bot can interact with members of the workspace through the slack client. In such cases, who installed the app is irrelevant for most practical purposes, since once it is installed, everyone can use it.

However, we install the app only for a particular user - and there is no bot that interacts with other members. In this case, if the workspace restricts app installs to admins, only admins can use Team Chat for vscode.

One way to fix this to change the app installation restriction to "pre-approved apps". In this case, admins still have control on which apps can be installed, but all users can then install the approved apps. I understand this isn't ideal, but I don't think there is any other way - happy to be corrected.

Attaching screenshot for the [slack app settings page](https://slack.com/apps/manage/permissions). Note that **Approved Apps** and **Sign in with Slack** are both enabled.

Additionally, I'm working on supporting multiple slack workspaces at the same time (#26), which will let you run all your workspaces together.

thanks @tibotiber. this helps a lot. here's what happened:

- the migration failed when the extension was upgraded to 0.9.0 (this needs to be fixed)
- if the local state is not reliable, the extension overwrites it by downloading updated state from the slack APIs
- but because the token is now invalid (since you've left the team), the API calls were probably failing, and the local state was never fixed.

I've created a new issue (#288) to handle such cases. thanks for your help!

@arjun27 What exactly goes through `karigari.chat`? My corporate proxy blocks it and doubtful they'd open it up. Any way to host that backend myself? I've already setup my own oauth redirect service as you outlined here: https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/issues/143#issuecomment-423188638

Hi @ssvalkyrie, `vscode://karigari.chat` is just an identifier to handle system-level URIs. When the OAuth succeeds, we can open vscode using a system-level URI, and vscode invokes the extension to handle the URI.

For more info on this, you can check out the [registerUriHandler](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#window.registerUriHandler) method in the vscode documentation. From the docs:

> the `my.extension` extension registers a uri handler, it will only be allowed to handle uris with the prefix `product-name://my.extension`.

The extension does not need any server/backend, aside from the chat backend itself (slack/discord). So the extension only communicates with the slack or discord APIs, there is no other intermediary required for the extension to work.

We do have a OAuth redirection service - for a convenient "sign in with slack" flow - for when you don't want to manually configure a token. This is purely for convenience, and has to be hosted at an https location since the Slack OAuth implementation restricts redirections to an https endpoint (if that was not the case, we could have used the `vscode://karigari.chat` URI, and get the redirection straight to the extension.) This OAuth redirection service is hosted on AWS Lambda right now, and the source code is available in this repo.

Hi @TAGC - firstly, I apologize for this experience. I understand how this would have been a problem for you, and I want to take this seriously. Please let me understand how this happened, and we can then find a resolution that works.

The extension does not do such a thing by itself. My hypothesis is that this was caused by the one-click Live Share session initiation ([as given in the Readme](https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat#with-slack-and-discord)) - which allows you to start a Live Share session with a contact/channel, and this then shares the invite with them. This gets triggered by clicking on the share icon next to the name of the channel.

If this is what happened, the user experience on the action should be improved, and we could add a confirmation to make it clear that it will share the LS link on the channel. That way, it would not be a surprise. I realize that it is actually very easy to accidentally click the icon, when one wants to click on the row to open the channel instead.

Again, apologies for the bad ux, and the unexpected outcome. It would be great if you could verify this, and I would then proceed to release a build with the fix

thanks @zetas. I haven't been able to isolate the issue, but I was able to identify a few improvements that to potentially fix this:

- use RTM (Websocket) for sending messages. since we have an open WS for receiving messages already, we can use the same transport for sending, and avoid any inconsistencies + additional rate limits. This was avoided earlier because of some open issues in the slack node dependency, which seem to have been fixed
- 5000 users can potentially lead to rate limiting on the `users.list` API. since we don't specify a `limit` while making the call, the slack node dependency auto-paginates the result (with 200 default page size), which will result in a burst of API calls. however, it is unclear whether this should affect the `chat.postMessage` call
- similarly, we also make a call to fetch historical unreads by calling every channel individually, which will could cause a rate limit error. we probably should switch to using the `conversations.list` API, so that our channels store is restricted to the user's channels only. [docs](https://api.slack.com/methods/channels.list)
- listen for `rate_limited` errors on the http client, so that we have more visibility on which calls are failing and how long to wait before the next call. [docs](https://slackapi.github.io/node-slack-sdk/web_api#rate-limit-handling)

I plan to release these improvements in the coming releases, will keep you posted.
Thanks for the updates, It's much appreciated. If you need any other debug info or help testing new versions please let me know 👍

hey @bananaboy21 - thanks for sharing this concern. The current discord token setup is not ideal, I agree.

As mentioned in [our docs](https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/blob/master/docs/DISCORD.md), the goal is to move to Discord RPC when it comes out of private beta. With that, all API calls will be mirrored via RPC, and authentication will use the Discord OAuth flow.

The [current ToS](https://support.discordapp.com/hc/en-us/articles/115002192352-Automated-user-accounts-self-bots-) prevent automating user accounts. I'm not a legal expert, but afaik, we are not automating any user activities with this extension. Happy to be corrected if you think differently.

Nevertheless, will keep an eye out on Discord RPC support, and migrate to it whenever possible

I just read the update notes for the VS Code Live share extension, and found this mentioned. While I think the idea is great, I'm pretty sure it is against the Discord ToS. I'm not a Discord developer, but from my experience working with Discord, any use of user tokens outside of the official Discord client is classified as "automating user accounts", and isn't allowed as such.

As an example, Discord have recently started removing the authorization token from `localStorage` on start-up, in an attempt to prevent users from grabbing their auth token. Of course, there are ways to work around it (like the link you provided in your docs, using an API request) but IMO, Discord has made their stance loud and clear on this - don't use user tokens.

Unfortunately, while the RPC API is a thing, I do not believe it provides a way to create messages; only receive them.
maybe a better idea is creating a webhook, and allowing users to add the url to the extension- allowing the extension to post messages to the channel using api requests, without violating TOS.
@bananaboy21 webhooks can't recieve messages tho
@arjun27 Once the Discord OAuth flow is out, then how can we remove the Discord token from vscode-chat.

Notice the `"delete"` key. I would say there needs to be a filter on the value. Akin to this:

```js
getUsers(): Promise<Users> {
    return this.client.apiCall("users.list", {}).then((response: any) => {
      const { members, ok } = response;
      let users: Users = {};

      if (ok) {
        // refer to next line
        members = members.filter(member => !member.deleted);
        members.forEach(member => {
          const { id, profile, real_name, name } = member;
          const { display_name, image_72, image_24 } = profile;
          users[id] = {
            id,
            // Conditional required for bots like @paperbot
            name: display_name ? display_name : name,
            fullName: real_name,
            imageUrl: image_72,
            smallImageUrl: image_24,
            isOnline: undefined
          };
        });

        return users;
      }
});
```

Thanks for sharing this concern @jasonwilczak. The third party server (which runs on https://vscode.chat) handles the OAuth redirection only. The service does not store the token anywhere - just passes it from slack to the extension. This was required because slack does not let non-http redirections on OAuth. You can verify this in the source code of the service here: https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/tree/master/oauth-service. Happy to point you to the right areas if you'd like to review.

You can also host this service on your own, and create a new "slack application" with your custom redirection endpoint.

Thanks for the fast response @arjun27 !  I'm working with our security team now to determine what course of action we will take.

If we go custom endpoint, what setting would I use in the extension to leverage it?

A custom endpoint would not require any changes in the extension config actually. Let me list down the changes required

1. Create a new slack application and get the client id and secret
2. Deploy the oauth service, and set the client id and secret as environment variables
3. Define the url of the oauth service as the redirection url for the slack app
4. Open the authorization url of the slack application, which will redirect to the oauth service, and then redirect to the vscode extension

Pre-release build 3 is available to download at [this link](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1Wz1rJg72cY2fhpyhzfW4kuycFXb4hrJy).

## Setup
1. Download the `chat-0.6.0-pre-3.vsix` file from the link given above
2. Open VS Code, and select the **Extensions: Install from VSIX** command from the command palette
3. Reload VS Code after the installation

## Authentication
To use Discord inside VS Code, you need to have your Discord token. To obtain your token, follow the steps [given here](https://discordhelp.net/discord-token).

This is an unofficial token setup, one that is used by other Discord clients ([Discline](https://github.com/MitchWeaver/Discline), [terminal-discord](https://github.com/xynxynxyn/terminal-discord)), and the recommended approach by a Discord team member, as [given here](https://github.com/discordapp/discord-api-docs/issues/69#issuecomment-223886862):

> Instead, log in on the discord client, pop open the web inspector, (ctrl/cmd shift I), and type localStorage.token in the console to get your auth token.

The goal is to move to [Discord RPC](https://discordapp.com/developers/docs/topics/rpc#proxied-api-requests) in the near-term, which supports proxied API/websocket requests with OAuth. Discord RPC is in private beta at the moment. If you have any suggestions to improve this flow, please share.

Once you have the token, run the following commands from the VS Code command palette

1. Run **Slack: Configure Access Token**, select "Discord", and paste your token in the input box. This will save the token to your system keychain.
2. Next, you will be prompted to choose your primary Discord guild (similar to Slack workspaces). If you don't want to select now, you can run the **Slack: Change Workspace** command to select your guild.

## Known issues

1. The extension is still branded as a "Slack" client, which can get confusing for Discord users.
2. For large communities (like Reactiflux, with 2.5k members) fetching member data can be very slow. Currently the extension only fetches data up to 500 members.
3. Unreads are counted only updated after the extension has been activated, which means messages that were received before you open VS Code are not counted into the unread count.
4. ~Message reactions, edits, file attachments, link unfurls are not supported currently. Live share (and other) links are not rendered as clickable.~ (fixed in build 3)
5. ~Users that are not a part of your selected guild, but with open direct messages are not fetched. These will appear as bare ids.~ (fixed in build 3)
6. Live share invitations can only be sent to users that have an ongoing DM chat on Discord (new DMs are not created by the extension)
7. For large communities, a loader is required while member/channel data is fetched. There is no loader currently
8. The current guild name is not displayed anywhere, which can be a cause of confusion (feedback welcome!)
9. ~For large communities, performance is sluggish at times while updating data in the tree view~ (fixed in build 2)
10. ~Reloading the vs code window prompts for workspace, even when the workspace had been previously selected~ (fixed in build 2)
Build 3 is now available for testing. Link and instructions update in the comment above

Thanks for writing in @adamabernathy. I understand the concern, and want to find a way out for us here. Before suggesting solutions, I do want to stress that the Slack token is only stored inside your system keychain, and only you have access to it. I can point to specific areas in the source code if it helps to verify.

Unfortunately Slack permissions do not have a way to restrict scope to a single channel. The only way we could accomplish this is by creating a new Slack user account for your workspace, and adding that user to the workspace as a "single channel guest". The same user account can then be used to authenticate through the VS Code extension.

Another possibility that we could explore is to make some permissions scopes optional, depending on your use-case. Could you elaborate on what you're looking to use the extension for?

Hi @arjun27, thanks for the quick response!

Some context, I work on a team that develops medical software i.e. HIPAA and we have to be extremely careful about software we use and communicate with.  My concern was any surface area that would expose our Slack tokens to external parties or the ability to a third party.  I suppose if the token is stored locally in the key chain on Mac (what about Windows?) then that would be ok.  Could you point me to those locations so we can review that?

Sure, definitely. Token is received as the result of a successful OAuth redirection

1. the UriHandler receives the redirection here: https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/blob/master/src/uri.ts#L14
2. and then the ConfigHelper saves it to the keychain: https://github.com/karigari/vscode-chat/blob/master/src/config.ts#L52

The extension uses GitHub's [keytar](https://github.com/atom/node-keytar) library to get/set from the system keychain. They use the Credential Vault on Windows. From their readme:

> On macOS the passwords are managed by the Keychain, on Linux they are managed by the Secret Service API/libsecret, and on Windows they are managed by Credential Vault.
@arjun27 thanks for that, it clarifies the issue.  I think we can close out the ticket.  Thank you for your time.

I did some more testing and found some interesting things:
1. A thread in a direct message seems to be marked as read properly. ✅
2. A new message in a channel that was already having the incorrect unread count actually cleared the unread count. BUT, the new message did not trigger an increase in the unread count. Example: A channel was incorrectly marked with 2 unreads (due to 2 threads). A coworker sent a message in this channel. Unread count stayed at 2 rather than notifying me of a new message. But then when I clicked on the channel and read the message, it correctly went back to 0 unreads.

Hope this is helpful in tracking down the solution to this issue.

Thanks for sharing this Yashu. If I understand correctly, the token was revoked manually, after which sending the messages stopped working. On the messages side that is expected behavior - perhaps we could add a useful loader + error state in upcoming releases to improve the ux.

Yes, you are right to point out that the API key is sensitive. We should be storing that in the system keychain using [keytar](https://www.npmjs.com/package/keytar) to ensure that there is no unauthorized access. Adding keychain support is on my list of to-dos. Can you share why the token had to be revoked?

> the token was revoked manually, after which sending the messages stopped working.

If the token was revoked manually or automatically, it should show/output some kind of error message in the UI of VS Code.

> Yes, you are right to point out that the API key is sensitive. We should be storing that in the system keychain using keytar to ensure that there is no unauthorized access. Adding keychain support is on my list of to-dos. 

You should not store the API key in the `settings.json` file. It is possible that people might use a extension like `sync setting` in that case, it is like sharing the API key in public.

If you any to hide the API for getting exposed, here what you can do.

You can see how [Sync Settings](https://github.com/shanalikhan/code-settings-sync) store the Gist token securely in VS Code _(not sure even that is the secure way to store the API keys or access token, I suggest you ask the VS Code for the same)_, without getting exposed. Sync Settings store the access token in `syncLocalSettings.json` inside `User` folder.

This can happen when a developer or other member of your organization posts their private token on a public forum or website (usually a code-sharing website like GitHub).

I've been thinking about this too, but perhaps in a slightly different way. The links I frequently click are Github links (eg, a link to a commit) or CI links (eg, a failed build on Travis). I've been thinking of integrating these natively to reduce my context switches. For example,

- A commit link can open changed files in a tree view, and clicking on a file could load the VS Code diff experience
- A CI link can open a webview inside VS Code to show the logs of the build that passed/failed

> Could you elaborate on a few of these, and what you would like to achieve by opening them in VS Code?

At my workplace we revolve around Bitbucket, so the majority of them are that. There's also the occasional Youtube video also. Are you suggesting you'd prefer to whitelist which domains open in a tab? I'm not expecting to achieve much, just a tab opening with the clicked link, loading the content. I don't care for history, bookmarks or navigation buttons. (Imagine when you click a link in Slack on Android and it opens the "dumb browser" which has just an X button to close it. That's basically what I'd like.)

Also, what if the browser was configurable? Nobody in our tech teams managed to figure out why so to bypass this I set my default browser to Firefox, which I never use willingly. Thanks for verifying. Unfortunately there's no easy way for us to debug your extension state, but perhaps I'll add some logging in the next release to know better. I did however find a scenario where this can be reproduced in my workspace.

- user A and user B are having a conversation in a thread on a channel
- user C is also on the channel, but not participating in this thread
- user C's slack does not show any unread count for the channel or for any thread. but when vscode is loaded with the extension it shows an unread count which cannot be changed by marking channel as read

(Note to self: this happens because the thread messages are recent by timestamp but not loaded when we call for channel history. That means “mark as read” does not know the latest timestamp and hence fails)

I can't be sure if this is the case with your workspace, and I haven't dug into how threads work to know any better. I'll work on this for the upcoming releases, and at the very least add better logging. Thanks for your patience!
I suspect this may also be related to #62.

v0.5.9 has a few improvements for unread handling:

- With #45 completed, slack clients will always remain in sync. If you mark something as read in a slack client, this extension will reflect the same
- Unread messages are now highlighted with a border on the right to make it easier to identify them
- With #62 completed, channel joining/leaving will not be counted for unreads
- #49 has also been pushed, so muted channels will be explicitly removed from the unread count

There is still a known issue with how thread unreads get counted as channel unreads (tracking in #92), and I will pick that up for an upcoming release. Would love to know if v0.5.9 fixes the issues you were facing @SholomAber, thanks!

Thanks for reporting this @dwdozier. This can happen in 2 scenarios

1. Only apps from the "Slack App Directory" are allowed (Error message: "Apologies, but Slack Chat for VS Code can’t be installed. This app isn’t listed in the Slack App Directory, so only workspace owners can install it.")
2. Only apps that have been pre-approved by admins are allowed (Error message: "Apologies, but you are not authorized to install Slack Chat for VS Code. If you’d like, you can message one of your admins and ask them to install this app.")

These settings can be configured at https://YOUR-WORKSPACE.slack.com/apps/manage/permissions

Reverse initiation is a great idea. I've found myself asking people to start a session, and this will simplify that. I have released v0.4.0 with an early implementation of `/live request`.

![mgwjsa2j5h](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/284612/42387394-c61b8bf4-815f-11e8-9c02-c1bb872560d2.gif)

There are some improvements/questions as a result of my first impressions on the flow. I'm planning to iron them out with the next few releases. Specifically,

1. I've kept the implementation stateless right now, but that can create some unintuitive scenarios. For example, multiple `/live request` in the same channel means multiple "Accept" links - clicking any of which will start a session. There is no state around the link being "accepted", and perhaps expired. I don't think that is required...
2. ...except for giving interaction feedback. While clicking on "accept" triggers the "Sharing..." in the status bar, it can be easily missed in normal usage - which keeps the user really hanging, and feels incomplete. Need to evaluate if others feel the need for this feedback too, and add that. Perhaps we could mimic the Slack app [message buttons behavior](https://api.slack.com/docs/message-buttons)
3. The initiator can auto-join the Live Share link as you have suggested - I was thinking of checking for the following condition: "if live share URL received and `/live request` sent by user in the last 15 mins, then auto-join"
4. Currently, joining the link reloads the VS Code window and loads the remote project. With an explicit click to join, this seems ok. But with auto-join, the window will reload itself on receiving a message, and might appear arbitrary to the user. Reloading the window also removes the Slack webview, which makes it look like a completely new context. Due to this, I'm not sure if auto-joining will give the correct user experience. Any thoughts on how to improve this?

I'm going to use `/live request` more in my day-to-day use, and see if that changes my early impressions. Would love to hear thoughts from everyone so that we can make this a great experience!

Some more food for thought: I was going through the original issue on this (https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/live-share/issues/422), and realized we could leverage the [Slack presence API](https://api.slack.com/docs/presence-and-status) for peer discovery. The API has a custom status field that can show active project label, or even the session URL. What do you think?

Some thoughts based on your comments:

1. What if we added a "Dismiss" link, that would expire/invalidate the request. That way, anytime an action was taken on the request (either accept or dismiss), the message would "invalidate".

2. I also like the suggestion of mimicking the message button behavior. From a UI-perspective, it might also look nicer to render buttons, as opposed to links. But thats lower priority

3. As I think about it, I'm not sure whether auto-joining makes total sense, so we should just hold off on that for now, and get a feel for the experience.

Regarding the user presence comment, I'd definitely love to discuss this! We actually started discussing whether Live Share should provide an abstract concept of user presence, that would allow extensions to implement 1) list of users, 2) whether those users are available, 3) a mechanism to communicate the share session with them. That way, Live Share itself could allow you to share with someone, using different communication mechanisms under the covers. I'd love to discuss this further!

I was exploring how we could improve the initialization flow by using user presence, and came up with this implementation that uses Slack as a background transport channel (not as a chat window).

![ucpgxobrla](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/284612/44145561-b09397ea-a0a9-11e8-875c-33d9b47b39c9.gif)

1. Host (left in gif) clicks on an online user to invite them
2. This creates a Live Share session (if not already available) and sends the link over Slack
3. When the recipient (right in gif) receives the link, she gets prompted with join/ignore actions

These changes are WIP, over at #38. We could perhaps have a similar experience for reverse initiation. Personally, I haven't used the `/live request` command much, but that could just be me.

Also, we could show online users (as "users available for collab") in the new Live Share tree view, with a one-click action to invite them.

@lostintangent, would love to get your thoughts.
Closing this as resolved. We can always file new issues to address specific changes beyond the “/live request” command and new online users tree.

@johnpapa Or maybe “/live share” could detect that you’re already in a Live Share session and simply re-send the join URL to the active channel/thread? That behavior should probably exist either way, and we can handle that entirely on the Live Share side.

Generally, the core Live Share experience should make it clear that you’re in a collaboration session (providing a visual status), without needing to rely on a chat command. In addition to the current status bar items, we’re also planning to implement a tree view for quickly seeing session status (shared resources, user locations), which could help here as well?

Closing this since the Live Share's tree views have been implemented.  Additionally, `/live share` in a new channel sends the same join URL.

Example for reference that works **without a web app**: https://github.com/wee-slack/wee-slack/blob/89864b5ab952b426e77cd76cc0941035335063df/wee_slack.py#L3107

Getting the `vscode://` URL scheme will make this a lot easier for users. Filed: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/53301

Since slack only accepts https redirect urls, we cannot use the vscode URL scheme directly. I'm going ahead with a simple server less service that handles OAuth redirection. Putting together a check list for this feature (currently wip)

- [x] deploy service that handles slack redirection
- [x] keep slack oauth secrets outside git data
- [x] update domain for service to be human-readable friendly
- [x] handle for uri and update vscode editor config after redirection to editor
- [x] update user prompt for signing in
- [x] update readme for new setup instructions
- [x] update contributing readme to cover new service info
- [x] open slack app to everyone
- [x] add command to sign in to slack

Scenarios to be covered

- [x] real-time: incoming thread-only messages should be updated in the thread list
- [x] real-time: incoming broadcast messages should be updated in thread list and main channel view
- [ ] real-time: incoming broadcast messages should have a way to open the parent thread
- [ ] real-time: if parent message of incoming is not in the fetched history, we will need to fetch more history till we fetch it?
- [x] sending: how to reply to a thread?
- [ ] sending: how to send a broadcast reply to thread?
- [x] historical: show number of replies on messages that have them
- [x] historical: click to open replies, with same formatting variations as channel messages
- [ ] marking read: evaluate the `subscribed` and `unread_count` keys in thread parent object. should that be added separately to the channel unread count?
- [ ] unread threads must appear differently than channels - maybe have a separate status bar item? or a different quick pick behavior
also the color is a bit off. Look at the input text fields, for example the search input field or git commit message input - we should replicate a similar style for uniformity
looks like cmd + A is an issue upstream. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8794

@coolweb published

I am not sure if this would make a big difference, currently, the DB is created on the module initialization. What would change creating a method and calling it? I think to check if the DB is ready will still have to be done.

It make a difference, in our case we want in some scenario delete the database on app starting. If your code is in a method which return a promise and that method is called into an APP_INITIALIZER provider in your module, it'll not create race condition. For the moment while our app is starting, your code start which create the db without store, our code do some stuff and then the rest of your code continue and try to create stores...
@coolweb we´r facing the same issue
Alright it makes sense, so I would think about passing a callback into the configuration to be called when it's done.. What do you think?

A callback'll resolve the problem but I think the standard way in angular is to use the APP_INITIALIZER factory when we need to initialize async stuffs, in the forroot you initialize sync stuff like config values. I use APP_INITIALIZER in some apps for this kind of scenario, some info here [https://www.tektutorialshub.com/angular/angular-how-to-use-app-initializer/](https://www.tektutorialshub.com/angular/angular-how-to-use-app-initializer/)

[about the name and the key path](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/32214815/indexeddb-what-is-key-keypath-and-indexname)

Thanks for that @michaelfdeberry, but unfortunately that approach doesn't seem to work either. I did look into async/await but had the same issue, unless I'm missing something else? This works for me: https://codesandbox.io/s/angular-e5qpq

However, something I did to avoid managing the store name was to create a very light wrapper around NgxIndexedDBService. It creates a new instance of the service for every store. 

https://github.com/michaelfdeberry/overseer/blob/development/src/OverseerUI/src/app/services/local/indexed-storage.service.ts

Ok, that's a async issue as well. You will want to use Promise.all to wait until all operations are complete.

I can provide an example when I get home this evening, but it would look something like this https://github.com/michaelfdeberry/overseer/blob/798aafdd9813c55dcd7761ca055e18b09532abbd/src/OverseerUI/src/app/services/local/machines.service.ts#L73

I updated the CodeSandBox, https://codesandbox.io/s/angular-e5qpq

This will invoke all the add calls and insert the promises into an array. Promise.all will create a single promise that will complete when all promises in the array are completed. 

I moved the setting of the storeName within the iteration as well to ensure that each add call will use the correct store.

HI @wmbutler ,

Here is a working example with your use case:

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-wsxsnw
You are awesome!!

I have it working now from a button, but I need to call an operation after my page loads. When calling from ngInit(), it complains:

```
You need to use the openDatabase function to create a database before you query it!
```

Is there a better place to call it from when the route loads?

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-vjxfzk

It's difficult to determine what is best for you or your problem specific. What you can do maybe is us it in the resolve of the openDatabase as I last changed in the stackblitz repo.  

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-s5nyfz

this.db = new NgxIndexedDB('healthdome', 1);
This line is also in your app component?

Yes, you are indeed trying to open the database before create it. Just so you can have a better idea, move the creation to inside the constructor of your app.component and you will see it works.

Anyway, can you provide a mini repo with to simulate your problem on stack blitz?
You can have a get function in your service that returns a singleton database and get this database in your app component, and then use it.

The direction I'm taking with the new version is aimed at outsourcing the hosting requirements which enables much more scale for Stretto.

If you're interested in using your local files I'm open to discussing ways for users to upload them to an external service and have a Stretto integration for looking up their urls. But I definitely want to unload the burden of reading/writing id3 tags and storing large files into a separate service. That way Stretto can focus on doing it what it does best, managing music and allowing for music discovery.

@benkaiser I don't know what service that may be. Have you considered starting that using the old code and calling it something like "StrettoLocal"? I mean, without being able to use my own library from a web interface, I personally wouldn't have a need to use Stretto.

Well, the branch still exists for the old code. Anyone is welcome to continue using that / maintaining that. You're not obligated to upgrade to the new version.

As for what service that may be, it would have to be implemented. Essentially a wrapper around amazon s3 or something to basically store the files online, and then a way in Stretto to import the metadata for all those files / keep them in sync. This is definitely beyond the scope of what I'm wanting to implement, but if someone wants to take charge I'll help out on the integration side

@benkaiser It's your own project and I have no right to judge your decisions in any way, but you really did have something special there, with Stretto being a decent solution that enables anyone to have their own cloud music player. Just my two cents.
I think the s3 wrapper would do the trick.
Closing this issue out as out of scope. Anyone wishing to implement a local connector / a way to upload local music to a service to have them streamed is welcome to submit a PR.

Hey,

Sweet project! I like a lot of aspects of what you've done, really nailing the user adoption with the server setup vid / platform support!

I'm actually taking Stretto in a rather different direction with the next version (see [next](https://github.com/benkaiser/stretto/tree/next) branch), with the aim being to use youtube videos / soundcloud songs as the backing tracks for the entire library, and only needing one server to store the users data / keep it in sync across devices but never having to store the music files themselves.
I'm planning cool features for that like import from Spotify and in-built soundcloud feed browsing but they are still in the works.
You can try out what I have working so far on this page:
https://next.kaiserapps.com/

So as you can see from this direction the underlying fundamentals are quite different, with my main goal being to make it way easier for users to switch to Stretto and not having to handle massive amounts of user media content. You're more than welcome to help out with Stretto, but I'm not looking to stick with user-managed libraries / servers in the future 😄

My main idea was to be able to create playlist, from search or library, by filtering (by artist, album, or other meta-data) the songs.
The motivation behind this feature is that it is not possible to search for an album from an artist and another album from another artist. Furthermore,  the queue and multiple selection are not easy to use (no queue clearing, easy miss-click, ...).
With search result, the playlist generation would add the songs to the library and create the playlist.

With this feature, it would be easy to generate a playlist from a mix : it would be done the same way it is done with search result.

Interesting, we should have handling for that:

https://github.com/benkaiser/stretto/blob/master/library_functions.js#L124

Perhaps you could put in some console output lines around there and then hard rescan that song (right click it -> hard rescan) and then see which points it's hitting.

Okay, thanks for the tip. Everything looked all right, so I just noted which songs had this problem.

It turns out that these files are in fact `mp3` files, however they possess no tag data at all. (I had converted them by decoding the `.m4a` files directly and piping the output into LAME... therefore no tag data was written.)

So, perhaps if ID3 title is blank, stretto can use the file name instead?

I feel like that's rather hacky... not listening to what the id3 tags say the data is (blank in this case).
If you're familiar with piping things around and such I'd recommend writing a script again to merge the filename onto all the title id3 attributes. Alternatively I'm pretty sure a program called [kid3](https://kid3.sourceforge.io/) can do that in bulk quite easily (does regex formatting and stuff too if you want to get fancy).

Going to close this for now as I don't think we should handle special cases when the id3 tags are set to blank.

1. Possibly but I doubt it, I own a nexus 6p running Marshmellow, so that is the version of android I'm not experiencing it on. Also I use chrome beta, but they shouldn't really differ too much at all.
2. Well you can build it with the same idea in mind, but it would have to be a complete rewrite to Java. I have thought about creating an android app and did some research / initial work with nativescript a few months back (a technology that compiles javascript to native Java/Objective-C. Also there is a lot of work in it and I for the foreseeable future will be quite busy with my university studies and then working.
3. Nope, not really. Most issues I get from people are either feature suggestions or issues with the desktop version.
4. It's mostly as simple as changing the bootstrap theme Stretto is using. But there are a few other things that have colors (the songs when you click them, etc) that you will want to change to match your color palette.

Okay, so the library we are using adm-zip was broken (see issue: https://github.com/cthackers/adm-zip/issues/127 ), and it appears adm-zip has not been updated in over a year, so I have switched out the zip library for [node-archiver](https://github.com/archiverjs/node-archiver).

If you re-pull from master and npm install again the issue should be fixed and playlist downloading should be super fast now. Are you installing from source @kitguy or are you using the pre-built packages on the releases page? If you are I might consider doing an updated release.

Ah yes! Apologies!

If you run the application, you will actually notice that if you fire up a web browser you will be able to go to http://localhost:2000 and you'll also see the music player!

The application window that gets drawn is using a framework called Electron, that allows Node.js applications that create a server (like Stretto) to be viewed as an application window and also generates binaries for multiple platforms.

If you would like to run the server component on it's own, simply [clone the source and run the installation steps](https://github.com/benkaiser/stretto#dev-installation-instructions).

Let me know if you run into any issues! I'll mark this as closed for now :+1:

Hi @myoblastic ! Thanks for chiming in. I have had thoughts on this idea. However this is how I would like to solve it:
- Music is still always served to clients
- when a client gives itself a remote name (through the remote setup dialog), others can control it

Currently the capacity of this is only to let the others control it through commands such as:

```
http://localhost:2000/command/my_remote_name/playpause
http://localhost:2000/command/my_remote_name/prev
http://localhost:2000/command/my_remote_name/next
```

(see README for how I setup keyboard shortcuts for this).

What I would like added, is a way to turn a current player into a controlling mode, where it looks exactly the same, but every click / command is delivered to the player it is controlling. This wouldn't be too complex, what would need changing is all the functions in the `static/js/player/player.js` would need to be changed to (when in controlling mode) push the command through to the remote player.

This would solve your requirements (I hope) if you just ran the player on the server (would need chrome or firefox installed), then you can opt in the other clients to remote control it. 

It's not high on my list of priorities to implement currently, but you are welcome to have a go at it and submit a PR if you want. I'm also happy to give you advice on implementation if you need it!

Also, this feature suggestion is already present on trello: https://trello.com/c/scqlw6yx/1-remote-control-support

Hey @ohnx , I'm working off your changes now and building an electron build. No promises tho ;)

For future reference to people looking for how to solve the jquery and bootstrap slider issues, turns out because in Electron the `module` global variable is set in the browser, it messes up jquery (and hence slider, because it uses jquery). The solution for me, because I didn't care about node-integration in the browser was to add `'node-integration' = false` in my BrowserWindow options like so:

``` javascript
mainWindow = new BrowserWindow({width: 800, height: 600, 'node-integration': false});
```

Alternatively you'll have to require jquery (and the slider... not 100% sure how to do that) into the browser window directly, see: https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/254

Thanks for the interest in the project!

I'm guessing what you are trying to achieve here is to have the commands control the play behaviour of the app? If so there is already a way to do that!

I noticed your `integreation.js` file simply wraps around the `player.someMethod()` calls, can you simply invoke the method on `player` from csharp?

Anyway how I have it working, is that you can run nmp through a browser, click the button in the bottom right `Remote Setup` and set the computer name. Then you can fire off calls to the server to remote control that terminal!
e.g. If I named my machine `example` then I can fire off the following calls:

```
// toggle play state
http://localhost:2000/command/example/playpause
// previous track
http://localhost:2000/command/example/prev
// next track
http://localhost:2000/command/example/next
```

And under linux I let my window manager ([i3](https://i3wm.org/)) do all the key binding / request:

```
bindsym $mod+XF86AudioPlay exec curl http://localhost:2000/command/example/playpause
bindsym $mod+XF86AudioPrev exec curl http://localhost:2000/command/example/prev
bindsym $mod+XF86AudioNext exec curl http://localhost:2000/command/example/next
```

I don't know what the equivalent in windows is, but just find some application that can fire requests to urls on keybinding.
http://www.autohotkey.com/ might be one tool that could do the job. Otherwise you could just use your app to sit in the background and recognise the hotkeys.

I'm currently using the built in web browser, so the `player.` functions can't be called (I just get a bunch of errors)

I suppose that I could fire HTTP requests in my app as well, but since the client-side javascript is accessible, it's easier to just control it from the app itself.

On my side on Windows 7, I have curl so I created a shortcut which point to :

`curl http://localhost:2000/command/example/playpause`

Then go to the shortcut properties and set a Shortcut key :

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/439158/10368399/4c8d7c70-6dd5-11e5-91e3-f32291604b91.png)

That's it ! All works well without using any third party app :)

Its based on the audio formats your browser supports. Firefox only allows mp3 if the system library is installed for decoding it. In chrome it just works, and yeah, so it depends on the file format of your music library and the browser you are using. For a format table, look here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Supported_media_formats#Browser_compatibility

So your options are:
- use another browser
- convert your whole library to a format your browser supports or
- add a feature to node-music-player for live transcoding (if a file is not in the format needed, convert it on the fly sending it to the browser and the file system)
OK, now I see why the same version of firefox works out of the box on OSX. The page clearly says that the OS or Hardware can give the support while Firefox itself cannot for patent reasons.
Yeah, so like I could probably provide some shim that uses flash, but I'd much rather not and do the transcoding option.

Hi Ben,

I got the solution. So, this is what I did.  
    1. Downloaded the Mac binary from http://www.cmake.org/download/ and installed it
    2. 'Tools > Installed for the command line Use' from cmake UI
    3. Cloned the taglib repo from https://github.com/taglib/taglib.git 
    4. Installed taglib by using following commands:

```
cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local -DCMAKE_RELEASE_TYPE=Release .
make
sudo make install
```

After this when I ran `taglib-config --version` command I got `1.9.1`. This solved my issue of `npm install`

Okay, since I had time on my hands, and I saw you were running debian 7, I decided I would download it, spin up a VM and try to reproduce your issue. And sure enough, I ran into your issue. The key problem is simply that debian 7 has an old version of taglib that doesn't work with node-taglib. To fix this I tried a few things and the easiest in the end was to uninstall taglib, recompile taglib from source and then link it so that it was in my path. Like so:

(as root)

```
$ apt-get remove libtag1-dev
# package gets removed
# clone taglib from source
$ git clone https://github.com/taglib/taglib.git
# makes a directory called taglib
$ cd taglib
# start compiling as per https://github.com/taglib/taglib/blob/master/INSTALL
$ cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release .
$ make
# wait for it to compile
# install it
$ make install
# symlink it (it's not auto-installed to /usr/bin
$ ln -s /usr/local/bin/taglib-config /usr/bin/taglib-config
# now test it worked
$ taglib-config --version
# should show 1.9.1
```

Now run `npm install` again and you should be good to go! :)

Hi @daltek ,

A key difference between node-music-player and subsonic and node-music-player is that although node-music-player works in a remote situation, it is usually run on a local computer. That said I do see that in the future running it as a remote streaming server.

I'm not sure exactly, but the cost of transcoding a song every single time a user wants to stream it sounds costly. I feel it would be a better option to convert it on the fly, but to pipe the output to both the filesystem and the response (standard output back to the client).

I also think that rather than making this the default, having a setting on the client-side that can be set that would then change the request url from `/songs/:id` to `/transcode/:id` which would transcode from whatever format it is in to mp3 (unless it is already mp3).

Do you have any coding skills to implement this? Info on the ffmpeg command that subsonic uses can be found [here](http://www.subsonic.org/pages/index.jsp). I'll take a look at the pull request if you manage to implement it (also keep in mind that I want to keep the dependency on just node.js modules so that it is easily cross-platform should I finish implementing that one day). 

I myself have [a bunch of features](https://trello.com/b/cXdOSOoR/node-music-player) I want to implement first.

Also this [ffmpeg library](https://github.com/fluent-ffmpeg/node-fluent-ffmpeg) (should we opt to depend on ffmpeg) can convert the audio codec and send the stream to two places just fine. It would look something like the following (with res being the response it is the response the client is requesting):

```
ffmpeg('/path/to/infile.flac')
  .format('mp3')
  .output('/path/to/outfile.mp3')
  .output(res);
```

Hi, I have not touched Orchard Core much, and not at all recently.

Having coded on Nwazet for O1 quite a bit I have a few opinions:

- ProductPart as is has too much stuff in itself: for example, I don't think that Price and Inventory belong there, but they should rather be separate components (likely parts) that attach there as needed. I think that ProductPart should only have a SKU, and probably no other property.
- The payment infrastructure should come with a "null" payment implementation, for store that "sell" products for free.
- OrderPart right now is I think too complex and rigid: making changes and additions to it from other features is troublesome.
- Globalization: B2C ecommerces in the EU should display final prices (including tax); B2B ecommerces in the EU sometimes may not; B2C ecommerces in the US display price before tax, because taxes there change on a state-by-state basis. And this is just an example I know.
- The checkout process should have easy ways to inject behaviour between steps (e.g.: you changed your address, so we must recompute taxes; we have an inventory integration, so right before payment I check the items are still available), or even inject steps (e.g. select gift wrap).

These are just off the top of my head.

It is common to have a different catalog of products per region so yes, I agree that price should not be attached directly to a product. Same goes with inventory for the same reason. Normally B2B requires the users to login to display prices mainly because you want to have different prices per retailers/business and also because a B2B should never sell to simple customers. You don't want to be a competition against your own retailers by displaying a lower price (wholesale price) than what's the standard retail market price. On B2B websites you will often instead see : "suggested retail price : $99.99 USD".

That's great feedback and a good opportunity to get those right. The module was initially designed for a small-to-medium US-based business, so this sounds like a good re-calibration of the requirements. We do have multiple prices available in the current version, through extensions that have been added over time, but a re-foundation seems to be in order. Shall we build some abstractions around pricing, and let implementers of those abstractions provide their implementation? We could still ship those with a default single price implementation that corresponds to the current behavior. I suppose in light of the suggestion to have a null payment option, this would go hand in hand with a null price provider (no need to provide a part for that, I think).

OrderPart: can you detail what the problems are and suggest a solution?

Checkout: do you think using workflows more generously for this process could help?

As another idea to help getting started with the module. Nwzet.Commerce could have an OrchardCore web project that can be run from the repository, and a recipe that can be used to have a basic configured store with some test widgets. That way you could see the module in action by just checking out the code from github and running the web project just like the blog and agencey demo sites in the Orchard Core repo.

Price for products:
I agree with @bleroy regarding having price abstractions, and I also agree with the fact that a part for price is not needed by default. I also think that such abstractions should support different ways to interact with price there, for example by "injecting" discounts and such.
We should also be able to have several implementations available on a tenant: for example, I may need a basic price on some products, and tiered pricing on others.
Price abstractions should also be able to "interact" with the shopping cart and the checkout process.

OrderPart:
My issue there is basically the same I have for ProductPart: I think too much information is being stored in a single object, and I'd rather see it spread around in more. For example, it has credit card information, but a payment may involve no credit card. There are workarounds and ways to handle that, as I did in the VAT PR where I added an interface to add stuff to the table being displayed in the order view. I think those that currently are workarounds should really be the norm, and we should have the most basic order objects, with all the other info being tacked on them.

Checkout:
I think the nicest thing would be a chance to design/configure it as a "workflow". Meaning, different features may provide something similar to workflow activities that can be combined together to build the checkout process for the shop. This concept is still embryonal in my head, so I can't explain it clearly.
checkout should be modular to support different ways to pay in every region.

This is great. I'm just hoping that this can be built on top of the tax extensibility I put in place. If not, I'd like us to think about how to fix the foundations rather than build a new thing next to it.

I think it can work with what's in place. I did a bit of analysis a while back and it looked compatible, but of course I should look at it properly again before writing code. A possible issue being that i am not a tax expert, and the cases I know to consider may not be enough

I have been going through my notes regarding VAT. Note that I'll talk about VAT, because that what is used in most of the world (inclouding EU): in the USA they have sales tax. There is no difference for what we are doing here, because the only actual differences are in accounting (as long as this system is not being used for specific import-export cases), so for the sake ofdiscussion here let's assume VAT and sales tax are the same and save us some time for now.

This way of handling VAT would supersede the current implementations: both `StateOrCountryTaxPart `and `ZipCodeTaxPart` could easily be "implemented" in the way I described above, under the assumption that there is a single product category.
Looking at the implementation of `ShoppingCartQuantityProduct`, I think it would be necessary to define (probably as a setting) a "default category": `ShoppingCartQuantityProduct` as a reference to the `ProductPart`, but there is nothing mandating the fact that the product should have the ContentPart we will use to mark its product category. This would play well with "replacing" the two tax parts above.

`ProductPart` objects have no tax-related properties in them, and this is good. I would possibly add some wording somewhere in the editor to highlight the fact that the `ProductPart.Price` is before VAT.

In `ShoppingCartBase.Taxes(decimal)` only the first `TaxAmount `is returned, being the one from the `ITax` with the highest priority (and with value greater than 0). The `ITax` objects are obtained by calling the `GetTaxes()` method of all `ITaxProvider` implementations. This makes me think that we only need one `ITax` object, that has that category/territory/rate table. The `ITaxProvider` would return that object. Extending things a bit, a very large business may actually need more than one of those objects, assuming they can have products shipped from different locations in the world. Hence, the ITax implementation for this feature would be a ContentPart, so that we may eventually have a bunch of ContentItems that have it. (I am not planning on figuring out right now how to dynamically ahndle priority there, so I'll just have an input with a number).

The other place in the code where `GetTaxes()` is called is in the `TaxAdminController`, in order to list the existing ContentItems that have been created for the taxes.

What's missing from the current taxes implementation?
We need the ability to compute taxes on single products/items based on category and region. For the "cart total" this is not an issue, but on the frontend, in the EU, you have to show for each product the price after application of VAT. You can do it for a "default" country of your choosing, and then have the customer pay the correct amount at the end (notifying them of the price change). On top of that, it would be useful to show on the editor for a product what is the price you are setting for the final customer. 
On principle, this feature could be "attached" to its own VATPart on the product ContentItem.

Let me know if this all makes sense so far.

I am having issues in writing retrocompatible migrations. I post those in the following gist:

https://gist.github.com/MatteoPiovanelli-Laser/2bf66dcf313a8b912492e63956dfb1d2

The idea is:
 - Moving the base implementations to their own feature means that the new Nwazet.BaseTaxImplementations needs to have a migration that creates the same table
 - If Nwazet.Taxes was initially not enabled, enabling it now moves its migration version number up to 4 directly, so it does not create the tables. Nwazet.BaseTaxImplementations can then be activated without issues.
 - If you already have Nwazet.Taxes enabled, its migration has run and created the table for `StateOrCountryTaxPartRecord`.
 - At this point, for retrocompatibility, since you have Nwazet.Taxes active, Nwazet.BaseTaxImplementations needs to be activated, so that you have the same exact functionality. However, it does not have to create any table.
 - My idea was to wrap `SchemaBuilder.CreateTable` in a try...catch block. However, it looks like something else is also failing, because with that code (see the gist above) i just get "Transaction not connected, or was disconnected"

disorganized notes I have on the design of this:

Each `VATConfigurationPart `handles a single product category (with controls to ensure categories are unique):
 - This is the part implementing `ITax`.
 - This would mean that from `TaxAdmin `we will create one tax ContentItem for each product category.
 - If in a `VATConfigurationPart` we set the category as the default one, this overrides the previous default (kind of like what happens when setting the HomePage in an `AutoroutePart`).
 - Handle somehow attempts to delete the default category.
 - We need a default category to handle the case where no category has been assigned to a product (maybe we only have one category in the whole store)
 - When in the `VATConfigurationPart` we select the hierarchy to be used for taxes there, the category is "added" to the `HierarchyVATPart `for the hierarchy and the `TerritoryVATPart `in all its territories (this latter part is where we will set the rate).
 - This means that `HierarchyVATPart `and `TerritoryVATPart `can each refer to one or several categories, because I feel there should not be a need to redefine hierarchies for each product category we handle.
 - There may be a way to add `HierarchyVATPart `and `TerritoryVATPart `"at runtime" to those hierarchies and territories that actually need it. May be by abusing the `Activated `event handler for those items.
 - `VATConfigurationPart `has also a default value for the rate: this value is used when computing prices to show at frontend whenever the selected destination territory for the products is not found in the hierarchy: for example, an EU seller would only need to define EU countries in the hierarchy, because that's where he has to apply VAT: sales outside the EU are VAT-free (on principle, excluding specific agreements with foreign countries).
 - Given that we have a destination territory, we can apply its rate for a product of a given category. If the territory does not set a rate for that category in its `TerritoryVATPart`, we look for it in its parent territory, and so on recursively until we either find one, or run out of hierarchy to climb up: in the latter case we use the default rate.

One thing to note, I think, is that this feature is only really for guidance of the people handling the finance of the ecommerce that uses it: it will do things so that when reviewing orders they can see for each product the tax due, but it should not be a replacement for an actual accountant veryfing those values.

Orders are a thing I would like to review at a later date, because they look a bit too rigid to me in the way they work right now in Nwazet.

The Italian for what I mean is "Categoria merceologica". That is the actual wording from fiscal documents. Google translates that to "product category".

Hello,

I am finally able to work on this some more.

I've done a bunch of this feature here: https://github.com/LaserSrl/Nwazet.Commerce/tree/AdvancedVAT

Basically, VAT configuration based on territories/hierarchies is in place. It works roughly like this:

 - Admin creates a VAT Configuration from the Tax Admin. That is basically the ContentItem (ITax) that represents what we were discussing as TAXCategory. Each fo these items sets a default rate that will be applied for products of this category whose destination is any territory that is not configured differently below.
 - In each Hierarchy in the site, Admin can select the TAX Categories, and configure a rate for each one. These rates will be applied to all products matching the category that are sold with destination to one of the territories in the category.
 - In each Territory in a Hierarchy, where a tax category has been selected at the hierarchy level, for each of the categories selected in the hierarchy the admin may define a different rate to be applied for that territory and all of its children.

Example: a store selling Wine and Books from Italy. Exports to the UK are large enough that the store is not allowed to use the Italian VAT when exporting there, while it should use Italian VAT for the rest of the EU. No VAT should be applied to exports outside the EU.
Vat categories defined:
 - Wine, with default rate 0%
 - Book, with default rate 0%
Hierarchy defined:
 - EU (with 28 territories, one for each country in the EU). 
    - For Wine the rate is set to 22% for the whole hierarchy
    - For Books the rate is set to 4% for the whole hierarchy
    - UK (Territory): has its rate for books set to 0%. Does not set a custom rate for Wine because it is the same as the one for the rest of the EU (I am not sure this is actually the case for the real world).

From that store:
 - Selling a book has an applied VAT of 4% anywhere in the EU except the UK, where it is 0%. Outside the EU the applied VAT is 0%.
 - Selling Wine has an applied VAT of 22% everywhere in the EU, including the UK. Otside the EU the applied VAT is 0%.

For each product, there is a new part where we can select the Tax Category. The value "Default" matches the VAT category configured as default.

I'll add a site setting to select the "default" destination country: by this I mean the country that will be used to estimate VAT on products when no destination country is selected yet. This is because in the EU we are required by default to show the final product price at frontend (provided that said price is allowed to change right before finalizing the purchase, in case VAT for the destination country is different that the one used for displaying products on front end). One option available for that site setting will be to show the price before tax, for US ecommerce.

Advanced implementations would allow to easily get the values "modified" by taxes.

This service would mostly be used when presenting stuff to the frontend, as a shorthand to those properties and to avoid managing the active features in some weird way.
That all sounds great to me. 👍

The rough idea for the data right now:
```
public class TerritoryInternal {
    public virtual int Id { get; set; } //primary Key
    public virtual string GUID { get; set; } //I think we may need this to import/export
    public IEnumerable<TerritoryInternal> ParentTerritories; 
    public IEnumerable<TerritoryInternal> ChildrenTerritories;
}
```
e.g.:
Territory: Italy
ParentTerritories: EU, Europe, Schengen, EuroZone...
ChildrenTerritories: the 20 regions of Italy.

I am still trying to figure out the best Orchard/NHibernate way to implement the n-to-n parent-child relationship between regions. Should I go as far as implementing my own `ISessionConfigurationEvents` for this? I am not an expert here, and I can't see a simple way to create the n-to-n to the same table using naming conventions.

The additional properties to a Territory are also giving me pause. I mean stuff like `bool IsACountry`, `bool IsAShipmentTerritory`, `bool IsATaxTerritory`. I don't feel these properties belong in the TerritoryInternal, or in the feature enabling management of Territories at all (except maybe `IsACountry`). The shipping features should "create" the `IsAShipmentTerritory` flag, set to true for territories that should "appear" when setting up or selecting shipments. Same deal with tax features and a `IsATaxTerritory` flag.
In my head, `TerritoryInternal` currently has a `Dictionary<string, bool> AdditionalProperties` of flags, stored in a table with a foreign key to the `TerritoryInternal` it belongs to. The fact that values there are `bool` may be limiting, but I cannot think of a practical example where I would use something that is not a `bool`, except maybe to add currency information down the line.
Another way would be to simply put the additional info in the ContentItem. That makes development much easier, but also makes the structure less robust unless we do something more: I could flag "Italy" as a country, but not "Italia" or "Italie". We would need some way to enforce synchronization of that info even beyond what we did for culture neutral parts and fields in Orchard, and that sort of goes against how Orchard works.

As always, I dislike GUIDs and think they should be last resort. Territories already have a globally unique name. Literally.

n to n relationships are always a pain. Let me ask this. Since this is fairly static information that we're going to read once per app lifetime, and rarely write, it seems like a full-blown relational model for it is way overkill. I'm wondering if we shouldn't make that a lot more lightweight by storing it somewhere as an XML document. The hierarchical nature of it makes it even more compelling IMO.
