_Original comment by_ **Bertrand Le Roy (Bitbucket: [bleroy](http://bitbucket.org/bleroy), GitHub: [bleroy](http://github.com/bleroy))**:

---

You're not missing anything: it's just that this feature has not been implemented and tested. It should be a relatively easy contribution if you feel up to it though.

My two cents on this:
What we are planning to do (re: automatic update of inventory on order) is to use a workflow. We would be adding Activities for this kind of interaction if they are missing (e.g., I don't think there is an `UpdateInventoryActivity`).
The reasoning is that some of the applications we are looking at don't need/want automatic updates of the inventory.

That's an interesting idea. If it were just so that people can turn it on and off, I'd recommend to just put it into a separate feature. However, I see how having the possibility to tie custom behavior to inventory changes could be very compelling. What I'd be weary about is if the feature depended on the existence and behavior of a workflow that can be modified by the user. As far as I can tell, there's a basic behavior here that isn't going to need to be customized: if product is sold, decrement its inventory. That behavior, I think, should not depend on workflows, and should be a feature that can be turned on and off. Now we should absolutely have workflow activities for inventory changes built on top of that. For example, a scenario could be: if inventory falls below 10 on any product, shoot me an email, or if this particular product is below 50, start its ordering process for 100 more, or whatever.
Oh, and it goes both ways, being able to not just trigger activities on inventory changes, but also to build activities that update inventory.

I still don't agree that inventory should always automatically decrease as the product is sold.
FIrst of all, there's a matter of defining when the product is actually sold. Is it on payment? What if the store takes bank tranfers, rather than credit card? The product then is sold when the payment is processed and received.
Or maybe you want to tie the decrement of the inventory to the moment you process the order and actually put the product into the hands of a delivery service. The the inventory qould change in response to an updated of order status.
Also, say we decrement the inventory because the checkout completed fine. Then the customer cancels the order. The invenotry should increase again, so we have to provide something there anyway.
Maybe again, I want to decrease the inventory temporarily before the product is even sold to prevent people from buying what you are trying to buy, and then eventually increase it back if you don't go through the checkout in a given time.
I am sure I am missing some cases.

My point is, automatic handling of the inventory is really complex. I see specific features being able to handle specific cases, however I I don't know what kind of "coverage" of the scenarios that would grant. I'd rather have all the blocks in place to build workflows to handle each case.

Again, we get into the topic of invenotry vs available inventory like we started in #92.

This is why there needs to be a default behavior that can be disabled by a setting or a feature, and workflow activities to enable the implementation of custom behavior.
In the case of my business, the behavior I wanted, and that could be the default, is that the inventory is decremented when the order is created.
Cancelling an order should put the products back in the inventory.
The cases where the system fails and requires manual intervention are rare, and also unavoidable. We should not deal with that by introducing more complexity. Manual intervention in rare cases is really not an issue, it's a necessity.

I see it now. The feature would handle the simple case. The lego blocks for the workflows would allow handling more complex scenarios.

I still have a doubt regarding this:
> Cancelling an order should put the products back in the inventory.

Doesn't that make the store vulnerable to similar attacks as those you described in https://github.com/bleroy/Nwazet.Commerce/issues/92#issuecomment-287101443 ? That is, if the customer is allowed to cancel an order.
No, because in order to exploit that, you'd have to create lots of actual orders, leaving your credit card number, then cancel them.

_Original comment by_ **Jeffrey Olmstead (Bitbucket: [ems](http://bitbucket.org/ems), GitHub: [ems](http://github.com/ems))**:

---

Thanks for the prompt feedback. The coupon cannot be retired as it can be used by multiple users, it is only limited to a single use per user not just the first user. It is possible that is unique enough to keep isolated to a custom module (even outside current coupons module). However, the thought of tracking discounts to understand how a price was derived at / can be audited seems to make more sense globally.

I have looked at the extensibility points and they all provide me access to "OrderPart" which contains "IEnumerable<CheckoutItem>". Inside of each "CheckoutItem" it only records the resulting discounted price, no direct insight into the discounts used to create the price.

I realize it is complicated because the process actually chooses the most applicable discount (i.e. min price for customer) so even if I knew the discount codes that were available I would need to still determine which were used. And since my Coupons are only applicable if the user enters a coupon code, they are unique to the user.

I will play around with "CartUpdated" and "NewOrder" to see if I can extend it that way and determine utilized discounts. The more I think about it, I don't ever think this needs to make it back to Nwazet.Commerce as it is likely unique to only the case I am looking at.

Any other thoughts welcome, will close this out in a day if no other thoughts.

There should already be an event that third-party code can hook into to extend orders. I would definitely have a separate table for the coupons. XML just won't do: you will have querying to do.

Submitted pull request #21 for this issue.

I also reviewed the report feature (very nice btw!) for places where line adjustments were missing. The only place I found was the Export action method of the ReportController. When calculating the total for each row, the line adjustment should be added to the price x quantity. Something like this:

```
#!c#

var quantities = order.Items
        .GroupBy(item => item.ProductId)
        .Select(group => new {
            ProductId = group.Key,
            Quantity = group.Sum(item => item.Quantity),
            Total = group.Sum(item => (item.Quantity * item.Price) + item.LinePriceAdjustment) // add line adjustment here
        })
        .ToDictionary(
            item => item.ProductId,
            item => item
        );
```

I'll submit another pull request to fix that. I couldn't find a way to run the export from the UI. I had to enter the URL manually. Is there a link somewhere to download the export?

Thanks for the feedback. I've converted the one-to-many relationship to infoset storage, implemented store-wide defaults and provided the ability to specify an absolute number or percentage. I'd like to add a few unit tests to cover the price tier calculation logic but am not sure how to use the unit tests included in the module. Can you provide some guidance on how to properly run them with NUnit?

_Original comment by_ **Bertrand Le Roy (Bitbucket: [bleroy](http://bitbucket.org/bleroy), GitHub: [bleroy](http://github.com/bleroy))**:

---

This implementation won't allow for the creation of store-wide price tiers, as I was mentioning in my previous message. What I was suggesting was actually very close to what you've been doing (I suggested having a part for overriding the store-wide discount). I agree now that discounts are not the best implementation, but I still insist that you need store-wide defaults. The "use tiered pricing" could become "override tiered pricing".
I would do a few things differently however.
I would not implement a many-to-one relationship, as that data is not going to be queried anywhere. Instead, use infoset storage with a serialized form of your tiered pricing data. Less complex, and better performing.
Allow for each tier pricing to be specified either as an absolute number, or as a percentage.
Add hint text explaining that tier quantities are the minimum quantity to trigger that tier.
Cheers!

_Original comment by_ **Josh Berry (Bitbucket: [joshberry](http://bitbucket.org/joshberry), GitHub: [joshberry](http://github.com/joshberry))**:

---

Thanks Bertrand. I experimented with this over the weekend and ran into a few challenges with the discount approach. 
- Discounts for tiered prices don't work (at least without modification) because only one discount is ever applied. This may be specific to my use-case, but I need to be able to apply a discount (ex. 10% off) to all price tiers for a product.
- If the url for a product changes the discount is no longer associated. I could try to automatically update the associated discounts but this feels awkward.
- If the (base) price of a product changes all the tier prices change as well. Again, this may only be a problem specific to my use case.

I prototyped another approach where I added a TierPriceRecord with a many-to-one relationship to the ProductPart. Then updated the ProductPart to allow users to optionally add multiple tier prices (quantity breakpoint, price). This seemed to work pretty well and allowed all the discount functionality to remain the same. The only change outside the ProductPart was a small update to the PriceService to grab the right tier price before calculating the lowest price.

Here's a screen capture of what the UI looks like:
![](http://berryweblabs.com/mockups/commerce-price-tier-ui.png)

I initially thought tier pricing would be better implemented using discounts too but after looking at it the second approach seems more straightforward. What do you think?

_Original comment by_ **Bertrand Le Roy (Bitbucket: [bleroy](http://bitbucket.org/bleroy), GitHub: [bleroy](http://github.com/bleroy))**:

---

Yes, this is something I'm interested in. I think it should be implemented as a discount. You should be able to set-up defaults site-wide (for example, qty 10-49 gives 10%, 50-99 gives 20%, etc.), with a possibility to override per item. This means that you may have to implement a custom part in addition to the discount. Makes sense?
Thanks for offering to contribute, and let me know here if you need any help with the design.

@using (Html.BeginFormAntiForgeryPost(Url.Action("Add", "ShoppingCart", new { area = "Nwazet.Commerce", id = productId}), FormMethod.Post, new {@class = "addtocart" })) {

productElement.SetAttributeValue("id",

Hi @jordan-miguel,

Try disabling all other installed plugins and themes to see if that fixes the issue. If so, it's likely that there's a conflict between a plugin and `hyper-cat-cursor`. Use the process of elimination to find which plugin that is and remove it. 

Otherwise, it's probably best to raise this question against the [hyper-cat-cursor repository](https://github.com/balazssagi/hyper-cat-cursor).

It's also worth checking if you are running Hyper v2. In v2, they have swapped out the underlying terminal, hterm, in favour of xterm, which significantly changed the interface many plugins rely on. If that's the case, just set your update `updateChannel` to `stable` in your config file and reload Hyper.

Cheers.

Yes we need to improve that.
It might be awesome if we can filter plugins based on this OS compat. But seems impossible with a `.md` based list.

It could be a lot of work to test existing plugins. How can we handle this? We can contact plugins author, but we should offer a way to make easy for the Community to help.

I wouldn't mind contributing along these lines if there was an obvious way to mark comparability requirements. Low tech is fine, even just a note on the row or additional column with OS icons would work. 

Ideally the package authors would note OS requirements in their own package.json... Maybe compat PRs to this list should point back to either an OS declaration in the plugin's package.json or a PR for the same?

What do you think about this?
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4137761/26760710/c24ad422-491f-11e7-901a-c1e7621db13a.png)

Love this idea, and it looks like that's a damn solid implementation. I have two concerns, neither of which are hard blockers, but something we should consider: 

1. How do we test and maintain this long term? What if a module adds support  for stops supporting one platform? Not a blocker, but would probably want to add some documentation around this.

2. Adding indicators means extension authors may need to know if their tools work on each platform. I don't know if we want to raise the barrier-to-entry of adding to the list by _requiring_ people to test/declare support for each of these platforms. Again, not a blocker but something to consider before implementation.

1. Most of plugins are fully compatible. Only some plugins have some OS limitation due to libs used. I think that plugin could only have better compatibility with time. It could have a temporary bug on a specific OS or a disabled feature, but most of time, compatibility will not be reduced but improved. In this case, I think that plugin author will be proud to update it in `awesome-hyper`

2. We can maybe change indicators to have 3 types for each OS: Compatible, not-compatible, untested (like non-compatible but with a interrogation point over it). If we want to do this, we need a way to have a community-driven indicator rather than plugin authors, but it will be complicated with a MarkDown. But I really think that plugin author can guess if his plugin works on different OS and accept issues on this OS. I think it will not be a barrier-to-entry for high quality plugins ;)

The best example is the [last approved plugin](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyper-spotify) which has a disclaimer about working only on MacOS directly in its README.

But you're right, it is a change with potential big impacts that need to be carefully weighed.

That looks very nice!

Some thoughts:

Plugins can declare OS dependencies in their package.json, e.g. I submitted [this PR](https://github.com/henrikdahl/hyper-statusline/pull/52/files) to hyper-statusline a little while back. It's likely not very well maintained but could be useful for auto-generating the initial info. Could also help in future to flag package changes for compatibility review. I'd suggest PR's here could point back to either issues or PR's noting/fixing/reporting compat issues for the package in question.

You could take a hard line and completely derive your compat data from that field and then just redirect folks to hound package authors to correctly declare their OS compatibility.

Aside from something along those lines I feel like relying on the community to keep the list up to date is your best bet.

You are right, we should use (and encourage) OS compatibility declaration in their package.json.
But it is better to not require it to reduce *barrier-to-entry*.

With my OS proposal, writing a row is hard with all these elements : name, description, OS badges and download badge. To make PR easier, I made a little tool to automatically format this row: https://awesome-hyper-linkmaker.now.sh

It takes description AND os-compatibility from NPMJS (so, from `package.json`), but user can modify them before copy/paste row.

We can maybe add a warning when user modify os-compatibility to encourage him to add/update it to its `package.json`.

I have no idea how to have feedbacks from community to keep this list up-to-date without a real website. Issues can be opened but it doesn't seems user-friendly.

I think GitHub issues would be a 👌 way to get feedback - if you try to download/use a module and it's not supported on the platform that `awesome-hyper` says it is, create an issue and we'll update our README. Could also go and create an issue on that plugin/theme's repository and link back to the `awesome-hyper` issue to let the maintainers know 😅 

I think the way to implement this would be to simply put a boilerplate paragraph in front of each section that states supported OS is community-maintained, and if you find that it's not accurate you can open an issue and we'll update.

I've been thinking about this for themes for a while - what would your suggestions for categories be?

Would be nice to at least group related plugins together – for example, `hyper-statusline` should be next to `hyperline`, and `hyper-lastpass` should be next to `hyper-1password`. Lots of other examples. At the moment it's just random.

Same for the themes – for example, all the `solarized` ones should be together. I appreciate that finding characteristics by which to sort or group the themes is harder than with the plugins, though.

If this is too difficult, even alphabetical order would be better than random, though nowhere near as good as a logical order.
(I know they are listed in the order they were added, but that's effectively random.)
How about we try to draft some general categories? Things like Productivity (1pass), Fun (the John Ceena one), and a few others. Maybe try 4 to start out with?

I agree, it would be a good start to create a few categories, and sorting them alphabetically would be neat.
I'll come back with some ideas.

### Productivity
Pretty much anything that changes Hyper to **help** the user, with no configuration needed, or not much.

Examples:
- [hyperterm-1password](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperterm-1password)
- [hyperterm-lastpass](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperterm-lastpass)
- [hyperterm-tabs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperterm-tabs)
- [hyperlinks](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperlinks)

### Customization
Includes packages that allows the user to change Hyper's appearance and functionalities.

Examples:
- [hyperterm-visor](https://github.com/CWSpear/hyperterm-visor)
- [hyper-stylesheet](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyper-stylesheet)
- [hyperterm-overlay](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperterm-overlay)
- [hyperterm-transparent-bg](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyperterm-transparent-bg)

### Fun
Packages that are not really useful, but adds a bit of entertainment in the terminal.

Examples:
- [hyper-john](https://www.npmjs.com/package/hyper-john)
- [htyt](https://www.npmjs.com/package/htyt)

And of course, we could sort all packages alphabetically.
Any suggestions?
@darahak Love it! Looks perfect. 👌

@bnb Should I wait for second opinions before making a PR?
Also, I'm worried about merge conflicts with other PRs if I apply an alphabetic sort on the lists.

@darahak Nope, feel free to submit a PR now! I think two steps is best - submit categories, and then  we can start alphabetically sorting once we've got categories to minimize the merge conflicts in the meantime 👍

FYI if I make the alphabetical sort, I will also need to update the contributing rules.

> Link additions should be added to the bottom of the relevant category.

For contributors who use Atom, it has a [package](https://atom.io/packages/markdown-sort-list) for sorting Markdown lists (could help if the edited list gets too long).

@darahak I was thinking about the sorting of them today. Ideally we'd like to not need people to jump out to a text editor to sort them correctly. I think the best way is to note it in the `CONTRIBUTING.md` file, in the PR template, and then manually check ourselves. when a PR is submitted.

One thing that would be nice is to automate it. At this point, I'm fairly frustrated with the build system we're using. I'd like to rework it, and would be interesting to see if we could integrate alphabetical order into the build process.

We could probably automate a check with [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.org/) for example and then, use something like [Danger](http://danger.systems/) to automatically ask for changes on PRs that don't follow the guidelines?

Could you please add a description with a bit more detail about why hypersixteen is a really awesome plugin? 

Just asking, as `awesome-hyperterm` is intended to be a curated list of the best Hyperterm packages, themes, and resources available, so we want to make sure the package, theme, and resource list items say why we think they're the _most_ awesome!

Thanks!

Absolutely! As depicted by the example GIF in the README, `hypersixteen` allows you to switch between any preexisting base16 theme available with ease. There are many existing base16 themes on npm, but they're not all centralized and in one place for easy access. This package allows that.

In addition to being able to switch between an existing base16 theme, you are also able to modify any of the base16 values (00, 01, 02, etc.) with just one configuration value. Say you don't like the foreground color of `base16-ocean`? Then all you need to do is change the foreground base16 color, which is base05. No fussy `css` or `termCSS` configuration.

Has to be done manually, I'll do my best to break down the steps:

Add the upstream repo to your local fork

``` sh
git remote add upstream git@github.com:bnb/awesome-hyperterm.git
```

Sync your local fork

``` sh
git fetch upstream
git checkout <your local branch -- mine was `patch-1`>
git rebase upstream/master # there will probably merge conflicts here
```

Resolve merge conflicts and commit locally

``` sh
# edited the README.md file to include the new entry and resolve the conlfict
git add .
git rebase --continue
git commit --amend
```

Force push the change to your fork on gitub

``` sh
git push origin <your local branch -- mine was `patch-1`> -f
```

Pain in the butt but it works!

For the reality on usage of test262-harness, I'd prefer to keep it as it is.

It's usual that most browser engines will not pass all tests and I take advantage of the output reported with failures and passings.

An actual non 0 exit indicates me not a test failure but a failure in running the tests which is pretty informative.

My suggestion is - for automated processes - to use the json output and filter the result contents.

Fair enough. For my use case, my strategy is to narrow it down to a list of tests that pass, fix or skip the others (using a preprocessor or custom CLI invocation), and then include the good tests in each PR build to confirm that there aren't any regressions, so "test failures" and "error running tests" are both things that would need fixing. But I can see how it would be more common to want a report of which tests passed and failed, given that the full list never all passes in practice. And processing the json output isn't so hard for me since I already am writing a wrapper script.

In case anyone still experiences issues here:

In git bash, `test/**/*.js` seems to only match one level deep by default. You have to enable globstar first via `shopt -s globstar`. If you do so, the glob pattern will match all the js files in `test`. powershell seems to have this kind of matching by default

More info here: https://www.linuxjournal.com/content/globstar-new-bash-globbing-option

Thanks for the review, @rwaldon! In addition to incorporating your feedback,
I've made a few other corrections:

- Correct `scenario` metadata for tests marked with the "onlyStrict" flag.
- Skip Test262 "fixture" files.
- Emit file paths relative to the specified Test262 directory.
- Run tests, taking care to do so in a separate process in order to avoid a
  limitation of the "tape" module: https://github.com/substack/tape/issues/160
- Correct interpretation of `paths` option

@bterlson there's one subtle detail in this patch that I should draw attention to: the `TestStream` object does not support globbing. To me, globbing seems much more like a CLI-based nicety--one that you wouldn't necessarily expect from a lower-level Node.js API. Users in those contexts can achieve similar behavior by discarding unwanted data events based on the `file` property of the emitted objects.

As discussed over the past couple of days, I'm interested in re-factoring this to support integration with the entire pipeline (not just initial test compilation). I think I've implemented all the review feedback so far; I'll be carrying those improvements forward in a new approach (hopefully coming soon). Thanks for the review so far!

I'm trying to use this to test the Flow parser and running into problems handling early errors. I want to ensure that the Flow parser can parse valid tests, and rejects tests that expect early errors.

as far as I can tell, it's not possible for the transform to know the test attributes. `agentPool.runTest` calls `evalScript` with `test.contents`, which eshost writes to a temp file, and the temp file is the only argument passed to `babel-node`.

since the agent doesn't know the test attributes, it can't tell whether the test was expecting an early error. If the Flow parser successfully parses when it isn't supposed to, I want to fail the test (e.g. replace the content with `assert(false, 'expected a parse error');`).

also, `agent.transform = ...` as proposed above would mean that the transform happens in the master process so it happens serially, right? that seems bad, I think the custom agent approach like `babel-node` is similarly flexible but parallelizes better.

Maybe setting some environment variables, like `TEST262_NEGATIVE_PHASE=early TEST262_NEGATIVE_TYPE=SyntaxError`, so that `babel-node` (or my equivalent) can handle those cases would work. But it looks like there's a remote agent which might complicate things.

Plus, for clarification: setting a folder will run the tests through each subfolder, similarly the behavior of the deprecated test262 python runner.

Edit: a `*.js` is enough to avoid going recursively to subfolders.

ok, I've fixed the PR removing the files duplication. This change limited the possible valid paths, but the valid options are still an extension from the possibilities before this patch. This change limits the tool from diving recursively on subfolders, unless it's explicitly flagged as a glob pattern:
- `test/built-ins/Reflect/*`: matches only the 3 `.js` files in that folder, skips the subfolders
- `test/built-ins/Reflect/**/*`: matches those 3 files + all the files from subfolders
- `test/built-ins/Reflect`: does not match any file
- `test/built-ins/Reflect/`: does not match any file

These are now only considering npm-glob patterns, assuming the path arg needs to be wrapped under quotes on *nix systems cli usage to avoid path extension.
at the end, this became just a small change. The nodir is working just fine.
The issue appeared to be shells doing path expansion (the star pattern is passed explicitly on Windows but not on other platforms). This is fixed in 2.0.4.

I hear you on perf - I'm working to address it. If you're curious, the answer is batch mode so we don't spin up a node process per test but instead one process per N tests (where N is approximately 75).

Compared to the python runner, this is already running way faster (they don't have multithread support except for a very short time). But further improvements are welcome given the large number of tests that are being executed (and the speedups in feedback loops to improve js engines).

Later I may look into options to make it work with pre-compilers (code-to-code converters). I'm currently not happy with the arguments passing option. But meh, any progress is good and I'm too busy to fix that specific issue for now (I should cut this excuse at some point though).

`test262-harness -r jsshell -e "ch.exe /ES6All" test/built-ins/TypedArray/prototype` should work (note the slash prior to ES6All). You can also pass args separately using the --consoleArguments option (helpful mostly when using a config file and you just want to override the arguments and not the executable path).

No, I'm not sure; but i believe you could use something like https://www.npmjs.com/package/require-for to pass a `require` into `runInNewContext` that was scoped specifically to the dirname of the prelude file?

@thorn0 @ljharb Would it be possible for you folks to use a tool like Webpack to bundle your polyfills into a string that could be injected via the `prelude` option? And in your experience, do you think this approach would generalize for any polyfill?

I'm asking this not (just) because I'm lazy but because that approach is host-independent. Polyfill authors could use it to vet their libraries across hosts--not just Node.js.

It might be possible but it would be inordinately complex, and the goal is to make using the harness easy.

If the hostType is node, I would assume I could access node features properly in the prelude.

I was attempting to run a test against the [promise.allsettled shim](https://github.com/ljharb/Promise.allSettled) and ran into this issue. `require` was defined, but it could not resolve the module

I went with @jugglinmike's proposed solution of using Webpack to bundle what I needed into a prelude file. The webpack config and bundled file is here: https://github.com/astlaurent1/Promise.allSettled/commit/631acd603fd556ab8005165c785a64faf71f0cbb. I suppose I could have done that in my fork of test262

After doing all that, in hindsight, it would seem relatively straightforward to support something like `--webpack-prelude <prelude-entry.js>`, where `<prelude-entry.js>` imports whatever modules it needs to and runs necessary bootstrapping code. In this case, the `<prelude-entry.js>` imports the shim, then calls the `.shim()` method to make `Promise.allSettled` available in the context of the test drivers

Pre-packaging the prelude like this also serves the added benefit of  not "polluting" test cases with module/import semantics. The bundling provides a nice boundary between what you're preparing and what you're testing

(P.S. See https://github.com/tc39/test262/issues/2112 for discussions on testing `Promise.allSettled`)

> Would it be possible for you folks to use a tool like Webpack to bundle your polyfills into a string that could be injected via the `prelude` option? And in your experience, do you think this approach would generalize for any polyfill?

[This is what we're doing for the polyfill in proposal-temporal.](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-temporal/blob/main/polyfill/ci_test.sh) It works, although it makes test runs painfully slow (I suspect) because the prelude has to be parsed and executed for every test file.

Some context around the API changes: http://strongloop.com/strongblog/node-js-v0-12-apis-breaking/#vm_vm_runinnewcontext_code_sandbox_options

> vm.runInThisContext() compiles code, runs it and returns the result. Running code does not have access to local scope, but does have access to the current global object.

vs

>  vm.runInNewContext compiles code, contextifies sandbox if passed or creates a new contextified sandbox if it’s omitted, and then runs the code with the sandbox as the global object and returns the result.

The current C++ working draft is [N4800](https://github.com/cplusplus/draft/blob/master/papers/n4800.pdf). It has no subclause [iterator.assoc.types.value_type]; `value_type` became `readable_traits` as part of [P1037r0 "Deep Integration"](http://wg21.link/p1037r0) which was integrated into [P0896R4 "The One Ranges Proposal"](http://wg21.link/p0896r4) that was finally merged into the C++ working draft.

`std::experimental::ranges::readable_traits` *does* have [a specialization for pointer types](https://github.com/CaseyCarter/cmcstl2/blob/master/include/stl2/detail/iterator/concepts.hpp#L113-L114) as specified in [[readable.traits]](http://eel.is/c++draft/readable.traits) in the working draft.

(Everything in the `cursor` subnamespace is an implementation detail of `basic_iterator` from the stalled [P0186 "Iterator Facade Library Proposal for Ranges"](http://wg21.link/p0186).)

The problem is instantiating the declaration of `__sentinel<false>`'s converting constructor:
```c++
constexpr __sentinel(__sentinel<!Const> i)
requires Const && ConvertibleTo<sentinel_t<R>, sentinel_t<const R>>
: end_(i.end_) {}
```
GCC is over-eagerly substituting `sentinel_t<const R>` despite that `Const` is `false`. The fix is to change it to `sentinel_t<Base>` to make it "more dependent".
Fixed by 1c5142aed93167f16142b51f61e2ac081d05de58.

This PR completes the transition of the algorithms from function templates with concept overloading to niebloids with `if constexpr` dispatch. Total CPU time for a test suite build on my home machine has gone down from 22:40 to 7:30; Travis CI times have changed from ~75 minutes to ~35 minutes.
For the record, I will not be niebloidifying range-v3. Support for higher-ordered programming is a feature.

`invoke(_result(_t)?)?`, `reference_wrapper`, and `c?ref` aren't implementation details or extensions: they are polyfills of those components for standard libraries which do not yet implement [P1065](https://wg21.link/p1065) - which currently is *all* standard libraries, since that proposal hasn't yet been approved. P1065 notably does not propose turning `std::c?ref` into a niebloid, so `__stl2::c?ref` shouldn't be a niebloid.

auto r = reverse_view{v};
```

... and have that deduce `r` to be `reverse_view<view::all_t<vector<int>&>>`. But `all_t<R>` is one of:

* `decay_t<R>`
* `ref_view<remove_reference_t<R>>`
* `subrange<iterator_t<R>, sentinel_t<R>, [sized?]>`

In all cases, there is a conversion from `r` to the destination type, so I think your suggested simplification is OK.

We should try it to be sure.

EDIT: In fact, all the conversions are implicit, so I think this constructor can be dropped entirely. `reverse_view{v}` can simply deduce to `reverse_view<view::all_t<vector<int>&>>`, which is `reverse_view<ref_view<vector<int>>>` and then the following constructor Just Works:

```c++
constexpr explicit reverse_view(V r);
```

Thoughts?

> Thoughts?

Yes, that had occurred to me. I have a mild preference for "converting constructor template" over "non-template constructor with conversions in the callee" to reduce the number of moves (as detailed in the pull request). Moves are supposed to be cheap, but not moving is cheaper. (It also has the nice side effect of localizing conversion code into the constructor that would otherwise be at each callsite when not inlining, but that's a secondary concern.)

Is it time to start suggesting guidelines like "Don't use concept refinement for overload purposes"?
This should improve error messages for overload resolution failure as well.

> Is it time to start suggesting guidelines like "Don't use concept refinement for overload purposes"?

I'm inclined to say "no" until we can determine *why* this particular example has pathological compile time. All of the cmcstl2 algorithms used pure concept dispatch before there was an `if constexpr` but only 2 of the tests take literally minutes to compile. I need to minimize a perf repro to throw at Jason and Andrew so we can investigate whether this triggers something nasty in the compiler or if it's a fundamental issue with the form of the constraints. Hopefully that will let us give more useful guidance; "don't do this with your constraints" rather than "don't use concept refinement". 

> This should improve error messages for overload resolution failure as well.

Ideally, compilers should prune candidates from the overload set whose constraints subsume the constraints of another non-viable overload before reporting overload resolution failure - much like how today they prune non-viable candidates when there are viable candidates. "Your Foo isn't a Baz" is plenty of information, you don't also need to be told that "Your Foo isn't a FrobnableBaz" as well.

I quite like the idea of

> Your `Foo` isn't a `BidirectionalIterator` because it isn't a `Readable`.

I imagine that would require lots of guidance via attributes.

> Ideally, compilers should prune candidates from the overload set whose constraints subsume the constraints of another non-viable overload before reporting overload resolution failure

Indeed!  [I wrote something about that a couple of years ago](http://honermann.net/blog/2016/07/18/refining-concepts-improving-error-messages/).  Sadly, ideas come easily, but implementations less so.

> I can't do `advance` yet, as `counted_iterator` provides overloads of `advance`.

You could:
* declare `operator()` overloads for `counted_iterator` in `__advance_fn` and define them in `counted_iterator`'s header, or 
* forward-declare `counted_iterator` and some `__advance(counted_iterator)` overloads here, recognize `counted_iterator`s in `advance` with e.g. `if constexpr (meta::is<I, counted_iterator>)` and dispatch to said overloads. [The first approach is certainly simpler; I suspect this one is ever-so-slightly cheaper at compile time since it doesn't add `operator()` overloads increasing the cost of overload resolution.]

[temp.deduct.guide]/3 says it's ill-formed to have two deduction guides with identical parameter-lists. I made this change in the proposal so we avoid making the standard library ill-formed until cwg gets this straightened out.

`ebo_box` uses the "pass-through default init" idiom (TM) to be fully general: it has no user-provided default constructor, and does not initialize `item_`. Consequently, a default-initialized `ebo_box` contains a default-initialized `item_` - allowing to avoid the cost of value-init when desired - and a value-initialized `ebo_box` contains a value-initialized `item_`.

If you want a default-initialized object of a type `T` that inherits from `ebo_box<U>` to be usable in a constant expression, then `T` must value-initialize its `ebo_box<U>` base.

If you want a value-initialized object of a type `T` that inherits from `ebo_box<U>` to be usable in a constant expression, then `T` must either value-initialize its `ebo_box<U>` base or use the pass-through default init idiom itself.

See https://godbolt.org/z/L5od64.

Someone (@tomaszkam perhaps) should check my work.

A word about why the `common_type` specializations are not necessary. All the view adaptors in [P0789](http://wg21.link/P0789) are implicitly convertible to Container-like things. So, a `view::transform` already has a common type with a compatible `std::vector`; namely, `std::vector`. (EDIT: @tomaszkam notes this already in his draft paper for San Diego, not linked here.) Nevertheless, it may be a good idea to add a `common_type<Range, Range>` specialization (the common type is `any_view`, which is yet to be proposed).

Also, this solution provides strong motivation for providing relational operators for ranges, which default to `ranges::equal` (for `==` and `!=`) and `ranges::lexicographical_compare` (for `<`, `>`, `<=`, and `>=`).

cc'ing @asutton and @sean-parent who have previously expressed the opinion that the "common type" as discussed in N3351 need only be notional, not manifest in a program. I may yet be convinced of this, but my gut says that if we are not checking it syntactically, the requirement will be ignored.

EDIT: I'll also note that once the ~~range-based relational operators and~~ `common_type` specializations are added to the proposal, the STL2 solution to this problem is _much_ shorter and easier to reason about, in addition to being faster. And contrary to what Tomasz claims in his paper, no compiler heroics are needed to optimize this code. It's just inlining and constant propagation.

> Also, this solution provides strong motivation for providing relational operators for ranges, which default to `ranges::equal` (for `==` and `!=`) and `ranges::lexicographical_compare` (for `<`, `>`, `<=`, and `>=`).

Egads no. WG21 *just* got done arguing that `span` shouldn't have an equality operator that compares the elements it denotes because they are subject to change by operations that don't modify the `span`. The element values cannot be salient to the value of a range that doesn't own those elements.

Oops, you're right about that. :-P

EDIT: OK, fixed. The relational operators were unnecessary anyway.

>> EDIT: I'll also note that once the range-based relational operators and common_type specializations are added to the proposal, the STL2 solution to this problem is much shorter and easier to reason about, in addition to being faster. And contrary to what Tomasz claims in his paper, no compiler heroics are needed to optimize this code. It's just inlining and constant propagation.

You have proved that there is single compiler (as the code can be used with only 1 version) and single machine that is able to give the same speed for STL2 and cmcstl. While you are ware aware [see your's blog post](http://ericniebler.com/2014/04/27/range-comprehensions), that compiler have given very different result for such test previously. Note that due Concepts TS requirements, we cannot check more than 1 compiler,

I can implement the same benchmark in range-v3 and show the same effect on any compiler (capable of compiling range-v3, that is). The only reason you were seeing any slow-down at all was because your STL1 code wasn't using pointers-to-members and your STL2 code was. That is, you were comparing apples to oranges. (Compilers do a poor job of optimizing pointers-to-members, possibly because they are not that common in end-user code.)

As for that old blog post, there are some views that are difficult for some compilers to optimize; `view::join` for instance, which is used to implement `view::for_each`. On the other hand, `view::transform` is pretty easy for compilers to optimize. I wouldn't use that post to conclude that ranges are inefficient or difficult to optimize in general. And it's certainly not the case that the `CommonReference` requirement on cross-type concepts has anything to do with clang's inability to optimize the Pythagorean triples example.

Few things regarding the request:
1) The code has UB, as a comparison of any_view does not match the comparison of the algorithms, i.e. the semantics requirements of StrictWeakOrdering are not satisfied.. This is important because the `any_view` is currently not proposed, so maybe not available for the user of C++20.
2) To make code shorter (compared to STL1) you are using fact that algorithms are functors (not functions), which again is not true for C++20. This may be fixed by changing the invocation to:
```
benchmark::DoNotOptimize(
     ranges::equal_range(
         itineraries,
         dates,
         [](auto const& r1, auto const& r2) { return ranges::lexicographical_compare(r1, r2); },
        toDates));

```

So, please provide a solution that actually works with current working-draft for C++20, or at least, it is proposed to be included. Any other option may (and probably won't be available) for programmers.

Yes, the difference is caused by the usage of -O2 vs -O3, however, the apps I have contact with consistently use O2, for them, we are seeing performance drop caused by compiler not optimizing the code - exactly the point I made in paper.

> Again, the STL2 code is shorter, simpler, more readable, and faster, even with the CommonReference requirement. The STL1 code defines semantically meaningless relations over apples and oranges. I see no reason for it.
I totally disagree about this statement.
1) The code is not faster for some build setting. -O2 is reasonable and as far as I know, widely used optimization level.
2) Readability is totally subjective.
3) Mathematical notation of weak ordering allows building relation of different types (see my point 3.2) and such relation as meaningful as any other weak ordering. Including additional requirement makes this relation overconstrained, as consequence, they are less generic - see points 3.3 and 3.5 in paper.

Superseded by #178.

Worse: it's a bug in the Standard. [`forward_list`](http://eel.is/c++draft/forwardlist#overview-4), [`list`](http://eel.is/c++draft/list.overview#3), and [`vector`](http://eel.is/c++draft/vector.overview#3) may each be instantiated with an incomplete element parameter `T` when the allocator parameter satisfies the [allocator completeness requirements](http://eel.is/c++draft/allocator.requirements.completeness), provided that `T` is complete before referring to (instantiating) any member of the resulting specialization of `forward_list`/`list`/`vector`.

Among other possibilities, that wording seems to require:
```c++
struct TreeNode { std::vector<TreeNode> nodes; };
```
to be valid. There is no mechanism to constrain the special member functions of these containers that doesn't lead to constraint recursion for this recursive case: `TreeNode` is copyable iff `std::vector<TreeNode>` is copyable iff `TreeNode` is copyable.

(To be fair, my "bug in the standard" statement is hyperbole. The Standard does not require that the containers have constraints in place to ensure that one gets correct results upon applying type traits to containers. I think the Standard *should* do so, but we've painted ourselves into a corner with the allocator completeness requirements where it's impossible to do that.)

Superseded by #136

> You can't bind a reference where an object doesn't yet exist!

This is [CWG 453](https://wg21.link/cwg453), for which the current PR (and other PRs going back to 2004!) makes it valid to bind a reference to a region of memory of size-and-alignment appropriate to provide storage for the referenced type. Practically speaking, I prefer the implementation that accepts a reference to one that accepts a pointer:

1. The function is useful for implementing standard containers, and accepting references sidesteps the entire issue of how poorly specified fancy pointers are
1. Standard library implementors don't get to use `&`, and `construct_at(addressof(foo.storage), arg1, arg2)` is *way* more typing than `construct_at(foo.storage, arg1, arg2)`

Given that both of these are "convenience for library implementor" arguments, I suspect WG21 would reject them and ask for a design that takes a pointer parameter if someone were to propose `construct_at` for standardization.

(Fun fact: `aligned_storage` cannot be implemented in C++. Only class types can have alignments applied to them with `alignas`, but only arrays of `unsigned char` and `byte` can "provide storage".)

> Given that both of these are "convenience for library implementor" arguments, I suspect WG21 would reject them and ask for a design that takes a pointer parameter if someone were to propose `construct_at` for standardization.

Not to mention the fact that [`std::destroy_at`](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/memory/destroy_at) takes a pointer; *I* would probably reject a proposal for `construct_at` that accepts a reference.

Yes, absolutely - I was wanting to get your feedback on `ReferenceableRange`/`is_referenceable_range`/`safe_subrange_t` (described in the commit message for caseycarter/range-v3@8a2102f5cbe4d764b5f2098beafa7ed245a36f7d) before I devise wording for `ref_view`, the modified `subrange` converting constructors/deduction guides and necessary changes to `view::all`.

> I'm uncomfortable with `ReferenceableRange` and the special-casing of `subrange` and `ref_view`. It feels too ad hoc to me. It would be nice if we could get to a place where begin(range-expr) returned dangling<iterator-type> if the result were potentially dangling. That is, we remove the deprecated `Rng const&` overloads of `begin()` and `end()` and replace them with generic `Rng const &&` overloads that wrap the return values in `dangling<>`. Then we can add overloads of `begin()` and `end()` for rvalue `subrange<>` and `ref_view<>` that return non-dangling iterators. The difference would be testable at compile-time. This seems to me to be more in the spirit of the design than an extra `is_referenceable_range` customization point. It would be surprising if `Range>` wasn't satisfied so we would need to think through how the concept plays with such a scheme. It currently would work fine since `iterator_t` and `sentinel_t` test with lvalues, but we would need to make sure everything is still kosher. Does this make sense? Thoughts?

> I'm uncomfortable with `ReferenceableRange` and the special-casing of `subrange` and `ref_view`. It feels too ad hoc to me. The semantics of `Range` and `View` -- which are subtle to begin with -- are getting muddied by this thing in the middle. It sets my Generic Programming spidey sense tingling.

While it certainly *looks* ad-hoc - there's a concept here with effectively no requirements but an opt-in trait - I assure you this is actually principled. `ReferenceableRange` is a concept that's been around since 2014: it is a refinement of `Range` that characterizes ranges which can be passed to algorithms whose returned iterators are guaranteed not to dangle. Previously, `ReferenceableRange` - as embodied by the `safe_iterator_t` alias - only admitted lvalue reference types. This change recognizes that there are rvalue range types which satisfy the requirements of `ReferenceableRange`.

The motivation behind admitting lvalues is that (non-`const`) lvalue references will not bind to temporaries. When an algorithm accepts an lvalue reference to a range there is a reasonable expectation that the range will not be destroyed at the end of the full expression so that returned iterators remain valid. The existence of `as_lvalue` in range-v3 attests that this property is heuristic: it defends against Murphy instead of Machiavelli. A determined caller can provide an lvalue reference to a range that will be destroyed at the end of the full expression leaving returned iterators dangling, but it's not possible to do so inadvertently.

The salient feature of lvalue references that prevents their iterators dangling is that the validity of iterators (and sentinels) obtained from an lvalue-reference-to-range is not tied to the lifetime of the reference, but to the lifetime of the referenced model of range. The iterators of the lvalue-reference-to-range are exactly the iterators of the referenced range. Put simply, they have reference semantics. 

It's fairly straight-forward to see that `ref_view` has similar properties. Like an lvalue-reference-to-range, a `ref_view` can only be constructed from a `ReferenceableRange`. `ref_view` also uses the iterators (and sentinel) of the referenced range as its own iterators. Again, the validity of the obtained iterators is in no way tied to the lifetime of the `ref_view` - validity depends only on the lifetime of the underlying object referenced. (None of this should be surprising: `ref_view` is by design a `Semiregular` type that is roughly isomorphic to lvalue-reference-to-range.) Given that it has the same properties, `ref_view` provides as much guarantee as "lvalue-reference-to-range" that returned iterators do not dangle. It is sensible to admit `ref_view` into `ReferenceableRange`.

The story for `subrange` is similar albeit with a few twists. A `subrange` can be constructed either from a `ReferenceableRange` or from an iterator and sentinel value. Since `begin` and `end` (modulo the deprecated behavior for rvalues) require lvalue arguments, the iterator and sentinel used to construct a `subrange` either came from a `ReferenceableRange`, or have validity that does not depend on the lifetime of any external range object (as is common for pre-Ranges-TS iterators). In either case, the validity of iterators obtained from the `subrange` does not depend on the lifetime of the `subrange` - it depends on the lifetime of the `ReferenceableRange` from which the iterator used to construct the `subrange` was originally obtained. (I'm deliberately ignoring the pair converting constructor here, which I believe needs to be made `explicit`. Even absent anything to do with `ReferenceableRange`, I think converting pairs of iterators and/or sentinels to ranges should require explicit action from a user, for the same reasons that we didn't add `begin` and `end` overloads for `pair`.)

With all that said, I agree that the name `ReferenceableRange` is too vague and that its expression as a concept here is janky. It occurred to me hours after pushing this that the concept lacks syntactic distinction from `Range` and that the semantic properties will be hard to express. Making the customization point user-specializable without any kind of syntax guards is a recipe for everyone specializing the trait and trashing the lifetime semantics of the design. `is_referenceable_range` should be an implementation detail - at least until the concept is better developed.

> It would be nice if we could get to a place where begin(range-expr) returned dangling<iterator-type> if the result were potentially dangling. That is, we remove the deprecated Rng const& overloads of begin() and end() and replace them with generic Rng const && overloads that wrap the return values in dangling<>. Then we can add overloads of begin() and end() for rvalue subrange<> and ref_view<> that return non-dangling iterators. The difference would be testable at compile-time. This seems to me to be more in the spirit of the design than an extra is_referenceable_range customization point.

I believe it is sensible for `begin` and `end` to accept `ReferenceableRange`, although I haven't given any thought to consequences. I'm less enthusiastic about `begin` and `end` returning `dangling` types for non-`ReferenceableRange` arguments: I would not want to lose the guarantee that `begin` returns an iterator and `end` a sentinel for that iterator without seeing a clear benefit. 

>
>It would be surprising if `Range<std::vector<int>>` wasn't satisfied so we would need to think through how the concept plays with such a scheme. It currently would work fine since `iterator_t` and `sentinel_t` test with lvalues, but we would need to make sure everything is still kosher.

I think this scheme has the potential to turn nearly all `Range`s (or `View`s, if we try to restrict the effect to non-containers) into `ReferenceableRange`s: `&`-qualified `begin` and `end` are incredibly rare in the wild, and I'm not sure how we'd distinguish between the `ReferenceableRange` `subrange::begin` accepting rvalues and the non-`ReferenceableRange` `std::basic_string_view::begin` accepting rvalues.

(Given my statement above about needing to develop syntactic requirements for `ReferenceableRange` to allow it to be user-extendable I'm not totally opposed to this idea, I just not certain this is the right approach.)

> I think this scheme has the potential to turn nearly all Ranges (or Views, if we try to restrict the effect to non-containers) into `ReferenceableRanges`: `&`-qualified begin and end are incredibly rare in the wild

That also occurred to me. The solution I was toying with is to change the `begin` and `end` CPOs to only look for `begin`/`end` _free_ functions via ADL when the argument is an rvalue. The onus is then on authors of `subrange`-like types to write such functions as an opt-in. It's a bit of a hack, but better (I think) than adding a new customization point.

The risk then becomes types for which users have already written `begin`/`end` ADL customization points with `&`/`const &` overloads, as that will make it appear to be "rvalue-safe". But for many (most?) of those types, the types of the begin and end iterators will depend on the const-ness of the arguments, making them containers and therefor not rvalue-safe.

>  I'm less enthusiastic about `begin` and `end` returning dangling types for non-`ReferenceableRange` arguments: I would not want to lose the guarantee that `begin` returns an iterator and `end` a sentinel for that iterator without seeing a clear benefit.

Agreed, I retract that suggestion.

> That also occurred to me. The solution I was toying with is to change the begin and end CPOs to only look for begin/end free functions via ADL when the argument is an rvalue. The onus is then on authors of subrange-like types to write such functions as an opt-in. It's a bit of a hack, but better (I think) than adding a new customization point.

This is a dark enough corner that the weird hack may be justifiable: we really don't want to make it too easy to use, or it will be easy to mis-use as well. I could live with this as an extension mechanism.

> > That also occurred to me. The solution I was toying with is to change the begin and end CPOs to only look for begin/end free functions via ADL when the argument is an rvalue. The onus is then on authors of subrange-like types to write such functions as an opt-in. It's a bit of a hack, but better (I think) than adding a new customization point.
>
> This is a dark enough corner that the weird hack may be justifiable: we really don't want to make it too easy to use, or it will be easy to mis-use as well. I could live with this as an extension mechanism.

Actually, I think we get what we want by changing the poison pill as follows:

```diff
-void begin(auto&) = delete;
+void begin(auto&&) = delete;
```

Then, after changing the CPO to only consider ADL `begin` functions for rvalues, we avoid the problem of accidental opt-in by `const&` overloads of `begin`.

The [CppReference.com](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/NullablePointer) page explicitly says "dereferencing (operator* or operator->) is not required of a NullablePointer type", so I am wondering its usefulness now too.

Is there another useful concept to check whether an object behaves like a pointer?

The Ranges TS doesn't define `NullablePointer` because that concept is not necessary to constrain the iterators and algorithms. If I were to do so, I would translate the Standard's requirements as (from N4659 [nullablepointer.requirements]): > 1 A `NullablePointer` type is a pointer-like type that supports null values. A type `P` meets the requirements of `NullablePointer` if: > > (1.1) — `P` satisfies the requirements of `EqualityComparable`, `DefaultConstructible`, `CopyConstructible`, `CopyAssignable`, and `Destructible`, > > (1.2) — lvalues of type `P` are swappable (20.5.3.2), These requirements together as a group are roughly equivalent to `Regular` from the Ranges TS. TS `EqualityComparable` requires `!=`, which Standard `EqualityComparable` does not, but that's ok because Table 28 below is about to add that requirement for `NullablePointer`. TS comparison concepts also require the result to satisfy `Boolean` which is significantly stronger than simply being contextually convertible to `bool`. I don't think this strengthening rules out many real-world models of this `NullablePointer` concept so I'll allow the strengthening and note it here. > (1.3) — the expressions shown in Table 28 are valid and have the indicated semantics, and > > (1.4) — `P` satisfies all the other requirements of this subclause. > > 2 A value-initialized object of type `P` produces the null value of the type. The null value shall be equivalent only to itself. A default-initialized object of type `P` may have an indeterminate value. [ *Note:* Operations involving indeterminate values may cause undefined behavior. —*end note*] This requires `P{}` to be an equality-preserving expression, and requires `P{} == P{}` to be in the domain of `==`. > 3 An object `p` of type `P` can be contextually converted to `bool` (Clause 7). The effect shall be as if `p != nullptr` had been evaluated in place of `p`. "Can be contextually converted to bool" is equivalent to the expression requirement `p ? E1 : E2` where `E1` and `E2` are any expressions such that `true ? E1 : E2` is valid. I would probably pick `true` and `false` for `E1` and `E2` just for simplicity and write this as `p ? true : false`. The second sentence is a non-syntactic requirement on values of expressions that requires that `(p ? true : false) == (p != nullptr)`. > 4 No operation which is part of the `NullablePointer` requirements shall exit via an exception. "Shall not exit via an exception" is notably *not* the same requirement as "shall be `noexcept`", so this one has no syntactic expression. We'll have to list it equivalently as an axiom of our `NullablePointer` concept. > 5 In Table 28, `u` denotes an identifier, `t` denotes a non-const lvalue of type `P`, `a` and `b` denote values of type (possibly `const`) `P`, and `np` denotes a value of type (possibly `const`) `std::nullptr_t`. Table 28 — `NullablePointer` requirements [nullablepointer] | Row | Expression | Return type | Operational semantics | | ---- | ----------- | ------------ | ------------------------ | | 0 | `P u(np);`
`P u = np;` | | Postconditions: `u == nullptr` | | 1 | `P(np)` | | Postconditions: `P(np) == nullptr` | | 2 | `t = np` | `P&` | Postconditions: `t == nullptr` | | 3 | `a != b` | contextually convertible to `bool` | `!(a == b)` | | 4 | `a == np`
`np == a` | contextually convertible to `bool` | `a == P()` | | 5 | `a != np`
`np != a` | contextually convertible to `bool` | `!(a == np)` | Rows 0 and 1 require `Constructible` and `ConvertibleTo` along with the semantic requirement that `P{nullptr} == P{}`. Row 2 is `Assignable`. Row 3 is the other half of TS `EqualityComparable

` as noted above. Row 4 and 5 together are `EqualityComparableWith` with the added semantic requirement that `P{} == nullptr` is `true`. If I got everything, this would be expressed in the style of the Ranges TS as: > ```c++ > template > concept bool ContextuallyConvertibleToBool = requires(T&& t) { > static_cast(t) ? true : false; > }; > > template > concept bool NullablePointer = > Regular

&& > ContextuallyConvertibleToBool && > Constructible && > ConvertibleTo && > Assignable && > EqualityComparableWith && > requires { P{}; }; > ``` > > Let `p` be a possibly-`const` object of type `P`. `P` satisfies `NullablePointer` if and only if: > * `P{}` is in the domain of `==` [*Note:* Since `P{}` is equality-preserving, `P{} == P{}` must consequently be `true`.—*end note*] > * `P(nullptr) == P{}` > * `(p ? true : false) == (p != nullptr)` > * No expression included in these requirements exits via an exception.

> The [CppReference.com](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/NullablePointer) page explicitly says "dereferencing (operator* or operator->) is not required of a `NullablePointer` type", so I am wondering its usefulness now too.
>
> Is there another useful concept to check whether an object behaves like a pointer?

There are certainly iterator concepts that could be usefully applied to require something to "behave like a pointer." The allocator requirements, for example, require an allocator's `pointer` type to satisfy `NullablePointer` and satisfy the requirements of a random access iterator and a contiguous iterator. Really it's a question of exactly which behaviors you consider to be pointer-like for your use case.

-Wstrict-aliasing only emits warnings when the compiler performs some optimization under the assumption that no aliasing exists.  When the compiler is not optimizing, it doesn't perform the analysis necessary to know there's an issue.

> Both pass. I get it's a bug, but why does `declval` pass here, when `ss` doesn't?

As Eric says, this is most definitely working as intended. Many of the Ranges TS concepts describe portions of the behavior of Regular types, because Regular types are fundamental to the design of C++ and the value-semantics-oriented design of its standard library. The concepts are essentially a recipe book for what Scott Meyers calls "do as the `int`s do." These concepts are as close as we can get to describing how C++ types "ought to" behave in the absence of other considerations, because these behaviors are in line with what the language and standard library have taught programmers to expect.

The (almost totally undocumented) design for output cursors is that you either:

* Don't implement `next`, indicating that your output cursor is position-less/write-once. These iterators usually do all of their work in `write`, and do nothing on increment. `basic_iterator` will implement an output iterator that acts as its own proxy type, i.e., returns a self-reference from `operator*`, redirects assignments into the cursor's `write` member, and uses the no-requirement implementation of postfix `++` to effectively return a copy since prefix `++` has no effects. This variation is necessary to implement `ostream_iterator` and the insert iterators as specified in the TS. 

* Implement `next` and don't implement `post_increment`. This is the "normal" mode of `basic_iterator` operation for `Forward` iterators: prefix `++` calls `next`, postfix `++` does the typical copy-increment-return-the-copy, `operator*` returns a proxy type that dispatches to `write` and/or `read`. This variation is typically not a good fit for purely output iterators.

* Implement both `next` and `post_increment`. Prefix `++` calls `next`. Postfix `++` calls `post_increment` and wraps its return value in an iterator if it returns a cursor, or returns it directly otherwise. (The existence of `post_increment` is an admission that `basic_iterator` is not smart enough to know which semantics you want for an input/output iterator post-increment operation. We give you a big hammer here to basically do whatever you want.)

* Implement `post_increment` and don't implement `next`, and see what happens. (The outcome is not designed, and should probably therefore be forbidden.)
Thanks for the detailed explanation regarding output curstors, <tt>next</tt> and <tt>post_increment</tt>.  That was very informative.

Why is it called `post_increment()` instead of `next(int)`? And I don't yet understand why it's needed at all. For the output iterators I've seen one or both of `next` and `write` are sufficient. @tahonermann can you put the increment action in `write`?

> But I agree with your point: we've crossed a boundary into a place where it would be easier to avoid `basic_iterator` and simply write an iterator by hand. This design needs to do a better job with this use.

I'm sure it can. `basic_iterator` already generates a proxy type for some cases. It can be made to generate one for this case as well.

> @tahonermann can you put the increment action in write?

@ericniebler, for <tt>otext_cursor</tt>, the increment of the wrapped iterator necessarily needs to happen in <tt>write</tt>; that is what lead me to suggesting this change.  The symptom I experienced was that, when an <tt>otext_iterator</tt> <tt>oi</tt>wrapped a forward-or-better iterator, post-increment/dereference/assign would call <tt>write</tt> on a copy of <tt>oi</tt> leaving <tt>oi</tt> holding a wrapped iterator that was not incremented.  The next post-increment/dereference/assign then wrote to the same location as the previous operation.

> Why is it called `post_increment()` instead of `next(int)`?

Because we don't have to differentiate prefix and postfix versions of the single name `++` - we can use different names and avoid the abomination that is `(int)`. I'm not attached to the specific name `post_increment`, but I strongly dislike `next(int)`.

> And I don't yet understand why it's needed at all.

I added `post_increment` because there are a few sensible semantics for postfix increment of single-pass iterators (and some more exotic) that I wanted to be able to express:

* copy-increment-return-the-copy: `move_iterator`, `istream_iterator`
* return-a-copy: Ranges TS insert_iterators. (oops - this is fine for `front_` and `back_`, but `insert_iterator` is broken in the same way as Tom's `otext_iterator` by this semantic: returning by value from postfix `++` means that the state of the copy is updated on write and then thrown out.)
* don't care (state is outside the iterator so increment does nothing and it doesn't matter to which copy we write): `ostream_iterator`, `back_insert_iterator`, `front_insert_iterator`
* return-a-reference (state in the iterator must be updated on write): `otext_iterator`, `insert_iterator` (broken in the TS: updates to the stored iterator are lost), `ostreambuf_iterator` (also broken in the TS: updates to the value of `fail()` can be lost)
* something ridiculously fancy: `istreambuf_iterator` (return a proxy with a copy of the current element and enough state to create a new iterator!) *This* is truly the intended use case for `post_increment`: do whatever craziness you like, and have `basic_iterator` get out of the way.

The current behavior for output cursors without `next` (return-a-copy) seems to be a mistake: return-a-reference seems a better fit for the known use cases. (postfix increment for iterator adaptors that handle both input and output iterators - `common_iterator`, `counted_iterator` - really doesn't have a chance.)

> `insert_iterator` (broken in the TS: updates to the stored iterator are lost), `ostreambuf_iterator` (also broken in the TS: updates to the value of `fail()` can be lost) 

Which is all on me: https://github.com/ericniebler/stl2/issues/137. Apparently we were thinking about `ostream_iterator`, `back_insert_iterator`, and `front_insert_iterator` when we decided to change all the output iterator postfix increment operations to return a copy instead of a reference, and not about `insert_iterator` and `ostreambuf_iterator`.

Tom fail.  This "fix" only works for cursors that don't implement `next()` or where `next()` has no side effects.  Output iterators with internal state and `next()` implementations with side effects must produce a proxy object for post-increment.  So, at a minimum, accepting this change would require adding a negative `cursor::Next<C>()` constraint; at which point, there is no need to dispatch to pre-increment operator++ and *this can be returned by reference directly, just as is done for the unconstrained pre-increment case.

```
constexpr basic_iterator& operator++(int) & noexcept
requires
    !cursor::Input<C>() &&
    !cursor::Next<C>() &&
    !cursor::PostIncrement<C>()
{
    return *this;
}
```

This suffices to implement stateful output iterators like `otext_iterator` that implicitly increment on `write()` and have no need to implement `next()` (or `post_increment()`).

This seems like a pretty narrow solution; I don't know how many output iterators this addresses.  Thoughts?

I was working on a `static_vector<T, size_t Capacity>` and looking at this `static_vector::insert` overload:

```c++
CONCEPT_REQUIRES(CopyConstructible<T>{} and Swappable<T>{})
constexpr iterator insert(const_iterator position, std::initializer_list<T> il) {
    // one cannot move elements out of an `initializer_list`...
}
``` 

I can easily constrain it with two "fundamental" (Range TS) concepts, but range-v3 also defines Insertable-like concepts. I was wondering if I should try to use those, define my own, or just stick to the fundamental ones as long as I can. I cannot really use the concepts defined for range actions since they would turn out recursive within the containers (e.g. insert requires that insert exist and works).

After the experience with static vector I believe that constraining `std::array` should be trivial. I wonder, however, how easy it could be to constrain `std::vector`. In C++14 I would have said that we would need to constrain `Allocator`s first, but IIUC most "troublesome" allocator methods are deprecated in C++17, I'd guess I'll have to try.

I've also found out that for testing whether a type's non-template methods are properly constrained explicit template instantiations are great, but this has resulted in me implementing workarounds to support explicit instantiating `static_vector<const unique_ptr<int>, N>` and similar crippled types. So obviously I wonder whether doing this makes sense at all. 

Is there a trick to find out if I've properly constrained something? I don't really mind _that_ much about over-constraining things _a bit_, but I would like to catch all the under-constrained functions. 
I thought I had properly constrained `static_vector` when `static_vector<int, N>` explicitly instantiated properly just to find out that I hadn't when I tried to explicitly instantiate `static_vector<unique_ptr<int>, N>` and then have it break another two times when I tried `static_vector<const int, N>` and `static_vector<const unique_ptr<int>, N>` (and now that I wrote this I realize I might want to try instantiating it with int& and const/volatile friends just to be _really_ sure...).

> ```c++
> CONCEPT_REQUIRES(CopyConstructible<T>{} and Swappable<T>{})
> constexpr iterator insert(const_iterator position, std::initializer_list<T> il) {
>    // one cannot move elements out of an `initializer_list`...
> }
> ``` 
IIRC `static_vector` uses a fully-initialized array of `T` as its backing store, in which case this function needs to copy assign, not copy construct. The constraint should then be `Copyable<T>{} and Swappable<T&>{}`.

> I can easily constrain it with two "fundamental" (Range TS) concepts, but range-v3 also defines Insertable-like concepts.

I would be leery of anything not defined in the TS: there are a lot of "ad hoc" concepts in range-v3 that are syntax without well-documented semantic constraints. 

> I wonder, however, how easy it could be to constrain `std::vector`

I have an archive lying around somewhere from a few days I spent trying to constrain `vector` and `forward_list` while respecting the allocator completeness requirements in the C++17 WP. It's messy. Consider that e.g. allocator-aware containers never directly construct or destroy objects of their element types: they only do so indirectly through their allocator.

> Is there a trick to find out if I've properly constrained something?

The best we can do right now is to test with parameter types specially engineered to meet only the minimal requirements. This is harder than it sounds, especially when the writer of the test is the writer of the component being tested. Your biases and assumptions tend to carry over from one to the other and inhibit effective testing.

> IIRC static_vector uses a fully-initialized array of T as its backing store, in which case this function needs to copy assign, not copy construct.

That's an optimization for when `std::is_trivial<T>{} == true`. When it is false it uses `std::aligned_storage` and constructs the elements using placement new on it using the copy constructor. I guess that the constraints don't say that if `T` is trivial, then copy assignment will happen, but if `T` is trivial, it is always `Copyable`. EDIT: maybe something like `(CopyConstructible<T>{} and Swappable<T&>{}) or std::is_trivial<T>{}` would make it more clear, but if `T` is trivial the condition left of the `or` is always true anyways.

> Consider that e.g. allocator-aware containers never directly construct or destroy objects of their element types: they only do so indirectly through their allocator.

This is what I thought as well, and what seems true in C++14. In C++17 `Allocator::construct` and `Allocator::destroy` (and `Allocator::adressof`) are deprecated, and there doesn't seem to be any replacement. I thought this meant that C++17 allocators only allocate and free raw memory, and that in C++17 it is the container's job to manage object construction and destruction. This would actually simplify constraining vector, since it can define its own `construct` / `destroy` functions that it can properly constrain. 

EDIT: I got it wrong: double checking it seems that the member functions of `std::allocator` are deprecated, but the `std::allocator_traits<Allocator>` static functions `construct`, destroy, ... are not.

> if `T` is trivial, it is always `Copyable`.

Not necessarily. A trivial class can have deleted special member functions N4606 [class]/6:

> A *trivially copyable class* is a class:
>
> (6.1) — where each copy constructor, move constructor, copy assignment operator, and move assignment operator (12.8, 13.5.3) is either deleted or trivial,
>
> (6.2) — that has at least one non-deleted copy constructor, move constructor, copy assignment operator, or move assignment operator, and
>
> (6.3) — that has a trivial, non-deleted destructor (12.4).
>
> A *trivial class* is a class that is trivially copyable and has one or more default constructors (12.1), all of which are either trivial or deleted and at least one of which is not deleted.

> This is what I thought as well, and what seems true in C++14, but in C++17 `Allocator::construct` and `Allocator::destroy` (and `Allocator::adressof`) are deprecated, and there doesn't seem to be any replacement. I thought this meant that C++17 allocators only allocate and free raw memory, and that in C++17 it is the container's job to manage object construction and destruction.

More precisely, allocator-aware containers are required to use `allocator_traits<Allocator>` as an intermediary instead of interacting directly with allocators. The deprecated members of `std::allocator` are no longer needed since they are equivalent to the default implementations of those members in `std::allocator_traits`. C++17 allocators are no less complicated than those in C++14, the only difference is that we've deprecated some members of `std::allocator` in the expectation that we won't have to support those "old" C++03-era members forever.

I may be mistaken in my interpretation of how constraints apply to non-template functions: they seem to be underspecified in P0121R0:
- [dcl.fct] paras 1 and 2 add an optional _requires-clause_ to the grammar for function declarations, but don't specify any semantics for it. (Para 2 seems to inadvertently omit _trailing-return-type_ from N4140)
- Para 5 and 6 discuss the "associated constraints" of a function declaration, but there's no connection between the _requires-clause_ and these so-called "associated constraints". ([temp] tells me all about the associated constraints of template declarations, and how they are derived, but there is no equivalent for non-template function declarations.)
- [over.match.viable] _does_ tell me that the associated constraints of a function must be satisfied for it to be viable, if only I knew where they came from ;)

Worked around in 23689d426768a1d153fae5a7204942f6d09c3866 by making `__counted_iterator::cursor::read` a template:

``` c++
template <class II = I>
requires
  InputIterator<II>() && Same<I, II>()
decltype(auto) read() const
noexcept(noexcept(*declval<const II&>()))
{
  return *get();
}
```
