I imagine it would be possible, but that's not the use case for `ranges::addressof`. It's not significant whether or not a user-defined address operator is `constexpr`, the point is to avoid calling user-defined address operators altogether.

`std::addressof` can't be portably implemented as `constexpr` since it needs to use `reinterpret_cast`; `ranges::addressof` is `constexpr` when used with types that don't overload `&`. (It is when `STL2_CONSTEXPR_EXT` is defined to `constexpr`, that is. The constexpr-ness of `ranges::__addressof::impl` is independent of compilation modes.)

None of this mess pertains to types which are required to satisfy any of the object concepts, since `Destructible` sensibly forbids `&` to return anything other than the address of the object. We can simply use `&` on them directly and avoid `addressof` and its `constexpr` issues.

Note that `STL2_CONSTEXPR_EXT` isn't well-tested or even applied uniformly throughout the library, thanks to GCC's `constexpr` problems like [PR67376](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=67376) that is also the current blockage for `constexpr` in range-v3.

> the point is to avoid calling user-defined address operators altogether.

IIUC they are still called through `std::addressof` when the type has an user-defined address operator, e.g., in variant's `get_fn`.  

The way it is right now, if variant is made constexpr, and it store types with a constexpr addressof operator, constexpr get wouldn't work because it would attempt to use `std::addressof`.  

Maybe this case cannot happen for a reason that I'm missing, but I was just wondering about this since IIRC Eggs.Variant also decided to do things this way.

Thanks for the explanation. I got the whole thing backwards. The only way to get the real address of an object in a constexpr function is if that object doesn't implement an addressof operator at all.

I don't disagree with this, but it seems that every weak input iterator can be promoted to an input iterator by giving it a trivial op== that returns true, right? Every position besides the last plus one is equivalent from the pov of a single pass algorithm.

Right - that observation is key. A single-pass algorithm cares about two positions: "current" and "end". It would be pointless to compare "current" with itself. It seems silly to me to require input and output iterators to implement `==` when nothing will ever use it. Conversely, `common_iterator<WeakInputIterator, WeakSentinel>` take advantage of that fact to model STL1 `InputIterator` for backwards-compatibility.

I can imagine 10 years from now having to explain to people that `operator==` is useless but they have to implement it because we wanted `InputIterator` and `OutputIterator` to look like their big brother concepts. I understand that it's nice to have things model `Regular` when possible, but `operator==` for what are really weak iterators is a minefield for programming errors: it's useless when used correctly, and UB when used incorrectly. In the near future compilers will tell us we can't compare `WeakIterator`s, but it will be quite a while before we can describe the semantics of `InputIterator` to the degree necessary for a compiler to diagnose `auto tmp = i++; tmp == i;`.

I think we'd be doing future C++ programmers a service if we:
- Eliminate `InputIterator` and `OutputIterator`
- Push the `Iterator` requirements up into `ForwardIterator`
- Weaken `Sentinel`
- Strip the `Weak` prefix from `WeakIterator` / `WeakInputIterator` / `WeakOutputIterator`

resulting in a smaller overall body of concepts without "boilerplate" constraints. (Some of this is speculative, I haven't done the legwork yet to be certain all the above are possible without breaking something in the design.)

But this would be the only public place in the design where we require op== without requiring Common. I've been resisting that. If we defined a constrained op== in namespace std for weak (in|out)put Iterators, would that solve the problem?

If the problem was only the hassle of defining the operator, I would let it go: we'll eventually have a tool like `ranges::basic_iterator` that can generate it for us. Similarly, it wouldn't take more than a half hour to define a specialization of `common_type` for `WeakIterator` and `WeakSentinel` that makes them seem to be `EqualityComparable`. What I see as being the true problem here is that the definition space of the predicate is so small: `==` for `WeakIterator`s - and non-weak `Sentinel`s for that matter - effectively has a precondition that the arguments are equal. The compiler should warn you that you are either wasting your time by writing a call to `==` or more likely committing an error. The best way to have the compiler diagnose that error is to not define `==` in the first place.
IMO, this deserves its own paper.

1c4621517edf7e3265b032fa35b56dbc280e4cac is a 40% speedup - still slower than I'd like.

cf293325418741d8f698b3fd43cb40559d4ae61c is memoization taken to the extreme - pushed as far as possible without obscuring subsumption relationships between concepts. The concepts are effectively decomposed into conjunctions of memoizable traits. alg.find_end compiles in 15 seconds. 

It is, however, not strictly conforming. Since the expressions are all hidden from the compiler, it won't know that e.g. an overload that requires `a == b` is strictly less specialized than an overload that requires `EqualityComparable<decltype(a), decltype(b)>()`. I hate to commit something so "loosely" conformant, but we're rapidly outscaling the compiler's capabilites.
Merged the memoization branch to master in 8650909a1dcd733d0b8d8c8b5562c59ab0c849e8. For the time being, we need a working reference implementation more than we need strict conformance.

> Determine why the std overloads are being selected by overload resolution

In the noted call expression, the first and second arguments are ranges of the same type. The 3-legged `std::equal` overload is therefore viable and more specialized than the `ranges::equal` overload that accepts two ranges of differing types. 

The fix would be to define equally-specialized-and-more-constrained signatures for all such algorithms.

> The fix would be to define equally-specialized-and-more-constrained signatures for all such algorithms.

Which requires roughly doubling the number of algorithm declarations since every iterator/sentinel algorithm declaration has the same problem of being less specialized than its iterator/iterator counterpart in namespace `std`. range-v3 sidesteps the issue by using function object algorithms which break ADL; I suppose users of the Ranges TS must simply become accustomed to explicitly qualifying any function name that also exists in namespace `std`.

We _could_ require implementations to address the problem without actually specifying all the requisite overloads. I don't have much of a feel for how the committee would regard algorithms-as-function-objects.

Problem was that I had an initial boot before applying patch for autoresize. Once I re-flashed SD and patched `cmdline.txt` correctly (before boot), then `./setup-teslausb.sh` run without an error.
Specifically remove the `init=/usr/lib/raspi-config/init_resize.sh` text at the end of the `cmdline.txt` file.

I am getting the same error. How does `cmdline.txt` have to look? How is this even related to the error?
```
Fixing the modules-load parameter in /boot/cmdline.txt...
Fixed cmdline.txt.
Starting to create backing files partition...
Checking existing partitions...
Modifying partition table for backing files partition...
Error: The location 7948206080 is outside of the device /dev/mmcblk0.
```
```
# cat /boot/cmdline.txt
dwc_otg.lpm_enable=0 root=/dev/mmcblk0p2 rootfstype=ext4 rootwait
```
This happened (in my case at least) because the whole disk was already allocated for the /boot and the root partitions, so the script tried to start the new partitions beyond the end of the last one.
👍 Thanks @justinporterfield / @divahno. You must edit the `cmdline.txt` _before_ first boot, removing the `init` part at the end.
After you flash the SD card but before you put it into the Pi edit the `cmdline.txt` file and remove the   `init=/usr/lib/raspi-config/init_resize.sh` text at the end of the file.

Rasbian Buster was just released - to avoid the error "InRelease' changed its 'Suite' value from 'testing' to 'stable'" execute   "sudo apt update --allow-releaseinfo-change" and then sudo apt upgrade. After this also the script will run.

Default configuration is that the normal as-you-drive files don't sync across - the Tesla maintains them as a 1-hour rolling buffer anyway.

All that's saved by the standard configuration are Sentry videos and manual save-this-clip (touch the dashcam icon and it'll change to a "download" icon, then bleep when that's complete). Clip-saving just saves the last 10 minutes out of the buffer.

Does the dashcam icon show on the car's screen? If not, setup didn't actually complete successfully.
Did you press the icon to save something? If not, there's nothing to back up, since teslausb only backs up saved clips currently.
Did you leave and re-enter wifi range, or reboot the rpi? If not, teslausb won't start the backup operation.

Ok might be the first one testing this then. I have a non AP 2.5 car so I do have have Dashcam only sentry. I am also powering the pi with constant power on the power port and usb on the other port. How does it kick off automatically usually?

Not sure how Sentry-only works, but on my car the files saved while Sentry Mode is active are saved the same as manually saved dashcam files, i.e. in folders under TeslaCam/SavedClips/
So first check that something actually got saved there: take the rpi out of the car and plug it into a PC, wait for it to boot up and publish the drive(s), and browse around on the camera drive.

The way the automatic backup process normally works is that once the car returns within wifi range, the drive(s) will be disconnected from the car (same as if you had unplugged them), mounted on the rpi, then the backup script backs up the saved files using the selected method, then reconnects the drives to the car.

I was having the same issue with the power going out to the USB ports.  I resolved the problem by powering the pi via the cigarette outlet.  Haven't experienced the issue again since I made that change a few days ago.

Providing another source for power, as @firedfly suggests, appears to work around the problem and my teslausb is once again working. Since the USB ports can deliver up to 2 amps at 5v I'm surprised the car is turning them off while driving. From what I can tell, a Raspberry Pi Zero W should only use 120-230mA of power, and I'm willing to bet there's something that can be done with the teslausb to have the vehicle continue to deliver power. I'm going to contact Tesla to see what, if anything, they might suggest.

Anyway, I hope this will help others to more readily identify what's happening.

Some discussion of this here, including an email response from Jeda who is also looking at the problem https://teslaownersonline.com/threads/usb-drives-dying-early-deaths-when-used-for-tesla-dash-cam-videos.11828/page-3#post-221333

> Our team has conducted extensive testing using the Jeda Wireless Pad and many other accessories that use USB cables. What we have seen is that when those accessories make use of the data wires inside a USB cable, the Tesla Model 3 resets or interrupts the power connection. By default teslausb will use all available space in the backingfiles partition for recordings and music, so it's expected to be full (there will be one or two large files in there, cam_disk.bin and optionally music_disk.bin that together take up all available space).
If you want to keep some space available, you can use my branch (therealmarcone/main-dev) and specify the exact size you want for camera and recordings, leaving unused space if desired.

I don't think swap is enabled by default (and I'm not sure you'd want to swap to an sd card), so that seems OK too.

@mg-chen - so it looks like your rclone drive configuration is not correct. you'll have to re-do it.

create the file as root with this command:

```
rclone --config  /root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf config
```

1. select "n" for new remotes
1. use "gdrive" for name
1. select google drive for type (should be 12)
1. leave client_id and client_secret blank
1. use drive.file as the scope (option 3)
1. leave root_folder_id and service_account_file blank
1. skip advanced config (n)
1. select "N" for autoconfig
1. copy the link to create a token
1. copy that verification code
1. say no to team drive
1. y to confirm

try the command again and hopefully it'll work

You don’t need to edit configure.sh to change REPO or BRANCH, the hard coded cimryan only takes effect if you aren’t setting the BRANCH and REPO environment variables. If you set the variables, it will pull the script from the repo you specify. 

Only need to run configure.sh once, it downloads the scrips to automate the device.
@jspv makes sense I think I was just being dense because it took me around 6 tries to get working haha. Does rclone only trigger automatically on boot or is it on wireless connect?

When you boot, archiveloop gets automatically run and keeps running forever. Archiveloop will check for a network connection, if it finds one it will sync the files. When done, it will turn the device into a usb drive and wait for a network disconnect and a later reconnect, at which time it will sync the new files and repeat the process.  

You can fake a connection or disconnect by touching /tmp/archive_is_reachable and /tmp/archive_is_unreachable respectively for testing.

Looks like the cmdline.txt has an initial script to expand the filesystem on first boot, so if you edit that while doing the rest of the first-time-setup stuff in the boot partition, it'll help.  Trying that now.

Using guidance here: https://raspberrypi.stackexchange.com/questions/56621/temporarily-disable-expand-filesystem-during-first-boot

I simply deleted the init= argument from /boot/cmdline.txt before first boot and that left the ~2G root partition per the image and left the rest of the device unallocated.  Running setup now - fingers crossed!

aaand, this is already in the repository somehow - I guess because of the way I'm doing this (on a chromebook) I'm not getting the benefit.

@rtanaka I just got back home and I have been trying to find any relevant logs. I don't see anything. The process I used to set up my Pi is non-standard. Here is what I am doing:

1. Start with a clean install of Raspbian Stretch Lite
2. Install nginx, php-fpm and php-mbstring
3. Install and configure rclone, download my website scripts, verify that my website is running
4. Change `/etc/rc.local` to do a filesystem check, run modprobe and prepare some temp files for PHP and nginx to run properly:
```
pi@dpi:~ $ cat /etc/rc.local
#!/bin/bash -e
_IP=$(hostname -I) || true
if [ "$_IP" ]; then
        printf "My IP address is %s\n" "$_IP"
fi
LOGFILE=/tmp/rc.local.log

function log () {
        echo -n "$( date )" >> "$LOGFILE"
        echo -n ": " >> "$LOGFILE"
        echo "$1" >> "$LOGFILE"
}

log "Running fsck..."
/sbin/fsck /mnt/cam -- -a >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1 || echo ""
log "Running modprobe..."
/sbin/modprobe g_mass_storage >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
log "Preparing temp files..."
/bin/cp /root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf /tmp/rclone.conf >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
/bin/chmod 644 /tmp/rclone.conf >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
/bin/mkdir /var/log/nginx >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
/bin/mkdir -p /tmp/php/sessions >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
/bin/chown www-data:pi /tmp/php/sessions >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
/bin/mkdir -p /tmp/log/nginx >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
log "Starting nginx..."
/usr/sbin/service nginx start >> "$LOGFILE" 2>&1
log "All done"

exit 0
```
5. Download setup-teslausb from this repository, export shell variables `RCLONE_ENABLE`, `RCLONE_DRIVE`, `RCLONE_PATH` and `campercent` and run the setup script 
6. Reboot

- "modprobe g_mass_storage", and the drives will reappear, this time correctly as music/cam drives
- repeat from step 1

OK, so it appears that the dashcam-side of things wants to see a partitioned device, and not an entire device formatted as fat32. In other words, if you simply
`fallocate -l 16777216K cam_disk.bin` and then `mkfs.vfat cam_disk.bin -F 32 -n CAM` like the setup scripts do, it won't work.
Instead you have to partition the image, then format the partition. At least that's what worked for me. Here's what I did:
- fallocate -l 16777216K cam_disk.bin
- fdisk cam_disk.bin
- create new primary partition: n, p, \<enter>, \<enter>, \<enter>
- set partition type to 'W95 FAT32 (LBA)': t, c, \<enter>
- write partition table: w, \<enter>
- quit fdisk: q, \<enter>

Verify you have a partitioned image with "fdisk -l cam_disk.bin", it should show something like:
```
Device             Boot Start      End  Sectors Size Id Type
cam_disk.bin1            2048 33554431 33552384  16G  c W95 FAT32 (LBA)
```
Now since mkfs can only deal with whole devices, you'll need to loopback-mount the partition you just created, so you can create a filesystem on it:

- losetup -o 1048576 loop0 /backingfiles/cam_disk.bin

(the number will vary based on how you partitioned the image file. In my case the partition started at sector 2048, so the offset is 2048*512=1048576)

Create the filesystem and teslacam folder:

- mkfs.vfat /dev/loop0 -F 32 -n CAM
- mount /dev/loop0 /mnt/cam
- mkdir /mnt/cam/TeslaCam
- umount /mnt/cam/
- losetup -d /dev/loop0

Now when you export the image as usb storage, the Tesla will recognize it properly.
For some reason this isn't necessary for the music disk.

Note that the cam_disk.bin image created this way will need to be mounted with the correct offset for the partition, so /etc/fstab needs to be updated to reflect that. In the above example, adding "offset=1048576" to the list of mount options should do the trick
https://github.com/cimryan/teslausb/pull/125 implements what I described above

Note that 2019.5.15 also writes the recording files in a different location, and with different names. Instead of creating recent-\*.mp4 and saved-\*.mp4 files directly in the TeslaCam folder, there are now two folders: TeslaCam/RecentClips and TeslaCam/SavedClips. Every time you hit the save button, it creates another folder under the SavedClips folder, and that folder in turn contains the saved files.
The subfolders are named \<date>\_\<time you pressed save>, and the files themselves also have a different naming pattern, \<date>\_\<time>-front.mp4.
I.e. you might see something like:

```
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-15-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-16-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-17-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-18-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-20-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-25-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-26-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-27-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-28-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/RecentClips/2019-03-11_17-29-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-12-06
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-12-06/2019-03-11_17-10-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-12-06/2019-03-11_17-11-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-13-54
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-13-54/2019-03-11_17-12-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-13-54/2019-03-11_17-13-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-15-05
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-15-05/2019-03-11_17-13-front.mp4
/mnt/cam/TeslaCam/SavedClips/2019-03-11_17-15-05/2019-03-11_17-14-front.mp4
```

So the various archive-clips.sh scripts need to be updated too, and possibly support both the old and new naming schemes for a while.

I was able to reformat the camera partition without rebuilding the Pi from scratch. It took me two days to copy all my music onto the SD card so I wasn't looking forward to doing it all over again.

_This will wipe out your camera partition,_ so copy off any clips you want to keep before doing this.

Here are the steps as I recall them:

1. Power up the Pi, wait a minute for it to boot and connect via WiFi, then SSH into it
2. Become superuser, make filesystem writeable, unmount the camera storage
`sudo -i`
`/root/bin/remountfs_rw`
`umount /mnt/cam`
3. Follow the instructions above by @therealmarcone: https://github.com/cimryan/teslausb/issues/119#issuecomment-471342299 **starting with the fdisk command** (skip the fallocate because you already have a disk image)
4. As referenced in his explanation, add 'offset=...' to /etc/fstab:
`pico /etc/fstab` or `vi /etc/fstab` as you prefer
    ...and add offset= (use the same number you used for `losetup`) to the cam_disk.bin line:
`/backingfiles/cam_disk.bin /mnt/cam vfat noauto,users,umask=000,offset=1048576 0 0`
5. Mount the new partition and you should be good to go
`mount /mnt/cam`

> I haven't tried this so I'm not 100% sure this will work, but I think that if you're using the `teslausb_setup_variables.conf` file to configure your system, you can just set the `REPO` variable's value to `therealmarcone`, and the `BRANCH` variable to `main-dev` (at the bottom of the conf file). This should then make the setup scripts pull the updated versions from my branch.

@nate977p Here is my 'fresh build' process.  I have this saved in a file so it's down to just cut/paste.  It allows me to use anyone's repo and branch easily.  Below it is set for my repo (jspv) and branch (main), replace accordingly.  Mine is pulls in the necessary changes from @therealmarcone (thank you!) and adds a minor tweak to handle the new subdirectory structure.  Just set REPO and BRANCH accordingly to pull in whoever's built you want.  

After flashing, setting the wpa_supplicant for WFi, removing any old Pi keys in ~/.ssh/known_hosts,   eject and put in Pi

```
ssh pi@raspberrypi.local
sudo -i
```
customize the next three lines to whatever hostname, and repo, and branch you want to use
```
export TESLAUSB_HOSTNAME=teslausb  
export REPO=jspv 
export BRANCH=master 
```
if you don't use pushover, skip the next three lines
```
export pushover_enabled=true 
export pushover_user_key=_my_pushover_user_key 
export pushover_app_key=_my_pushover_app_key
```
next steps are for rclone setup
`curl -L https://raw.github.com/pageauc/rclone4pi/master/rclone-install.sh | bash`
you can now do `rclone config` or if you know your settings, just write them to the conf file.  Below are my settings for using AWS S3
```
cat > /root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf
[teslas3]
type = s3
provider = AWS
access_key_id =_my_AWS Access Key_
secret_access_key = __my_AWS_Secret_Access_Key_
region = us-east-1
server_side_encryption = AES256
<ctrl-D>
export RCLONE_PATH=_My_AWS_S3_Bucket_Name_
export RCLONE_DRIVE=teslas3
```
almost done, grab the setup and run it
```
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/$REPO/teslausb/$BRANCH/setup/pi/setup-teslausb
./setup-teslausb
exit
passwd
```
(change passwd)
`sudo halt`
sometimes the archive doesn't actually get configured, don't know why yet - but if it isn't configured:
(login)
```
mount / -o remount,rw
BRANCH=master
export REPO=jspv
export ARCHIVE_SYSTEM=rclone
export RCLONE_PATH=_My_AWS_S3_Bucket_Name_
export RCLONE_DRIVE=teslas3
export pushover_enabled=true
export pushover_user_key=_my_pushover_user_key 
export pushover_app_key=_my_pushover_app_key
./configure.sh
reboot
```

the archive-clips.sh code for rclone leaves the directories intact. This causes the code to try and move the empty directories to the destination archive which results in nothing actually being uploaded but causing the process to delay the USB host connection by several minutes (depending on how many directories are present).
This creates confusion when connected to the car (if you're not reading the logs every time there is a delay), since the MCU can also stop recognizing the drive and require a restart.

I tested adding the following command after the loop to remove all empty directories so the next time the archive is run it will not have to contend with the empty directories.

`find "$CAM_MOUNT"/TeslaCam/SavedClips -type d -empty -delete`

Also added the following comment as a reminder why this is there:

`# After the file moving loop completes, remove all empty directories, as they cause the archiveloop to try and move the directories to the destination which takes several minutes and delays the usb host mount causing confusion as the drives are not detected and nothing is actually uploaded.`

I encountered this problem with [v1.2 of the marcone fork](https://github.com/marcone/teslausb/releases/tag/v1.2a). The following fix worked for me.
`/root/bin/remountfs_rw`
`export RCLONE_CONFIG="/root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf"`
`rclone config`
After which I obviously had to repeat rclone configuration, but you could just as easily move your rclone configuration file to the appropriate directory.

It would be helpful to add `export RCLONE_CONFIG="/root/.config/rclone/rclone.conf"` to the [instructions for RClone setup](https://github.com/cimryan/teslausb/blob/master/doc/SetupRClone.md). It should be performed prior to executing `rclone config` so that the configuration file is created in the directory that the teslaUSB scripts expect.

Using btrfs as a means of copying the cam files while the drive is still being used is clever.

Moving saved clips off the drive will require disconnecting the virtual drive from the Tesla. It seems reasonable to disconnect the drive just before archiving.

Copying the ephemeral cam files seems like it would be another set of steps in archiveloop.

> Moving saved clips off the drive will require disconnecting the virtual drive from the Tesla. It seems reasonable to disconnect the drive just before archiving.

> Copying the ephemeral cam files seems like it would be another set of steps in archiveloop.

I have a few thoughts here; for example, we could have pre-mount actions that move off existing files, and/or a configurable prune routine (by space, by date, etc.). 

All things being equal, I don't love disconnecting the drive, but I can't empirically prove that it's not the best way to do things. :) It just seems cleaner to say "once the drive is online, it has one goal: stay online and stable", since its purpose is to be as available as possible in case the footage is needed.

Figured out a solution unless someone has a better one.

Get mediainfo CLI (unpack to C;\Util\MediaInfo) and use the following windows batch script:

```
@echo off
set "exe=C:\Util\MediaInfo\MediaInfo.exe"
for /r %%a in (*.mp4) do (
"%exe%" -f "%%a" |find "Height" | findstr /r "[960]" >nul && xcopy "%%a" /y X:\Surveillance\Model_3
)
del /f /q .\*.mp4
```

This copies only the video files that MediaInfo has determined to have a frame height to the X:\Surveillance\Model_3 folder from the current folder and then deletes all mp4 files from the current folder.

i've actually used a Pi for something similar to what you're discussing. while it is possible for the Pi to act as either a client or an AP, it cannot do both at the same time. so doing something like you describe would be a little tricky since the syncing requires that it be in client mode waiting for a AP to connect to. unless someone has a clever way of switching between the two modes, short of adding a second WiFi dongle (which i am not a fan of) i'm not sure we can do something here.

that said, i've actually been thinking about this quite a bit and have a couple options i'd like to discuss

1. add support for having a non-syncing wifi connection for phones with mobile hotspot. i don't think it makes sense to sync over mobile but we can at least use this for emergency purposes like the scenario you described. in this mode we'd be able to go to a webpage where we can sync selective files just as you described.

1. leverage bluetooth somehow. i *feel* like this is the most elegant way... unfortunately, i'm not as well versed on leveraging this. i plan on doing some research here but i *feel* like we can use bluetooth.

looking forward to other thoughts...

I'd like there to be one entry-point script for manual setup rather than two. I'd like for verification of parameters and reachability of archives to be checked as early as possible, preferably before any persistent changes to the Pi are made. (I'm flexible on changes to /tmp since they get blown away with reboot.)

I'd like to avoid a model in which the configuration can fail midway through the setup process.

I think we can achieve these goals by extracting all verification logic so that it can be separately (but consistently) invoked from setup-teslausb, configure, and even after having written the config file used by the one-step setup but before booting the Pi.

Given the nature and significance of the changes that we're still making supporting upgrade seems like it'll be challenging. Even communicating the scope of a simplified
upgrade seems difficult. I vote that we defer tackling upgrade, at least for this PR.

Reflashing is pretty quick. Maybe it's just because I'm practiced, but it takes me just a few minutes to reflash and set up a Pi from scratch. If the idea is that we want to enable people to apply customizations after the install process maybe we can make that explicitly an option. Maybe we make setup-teslausb call a "/boot/customize-setup.sh" if one exists before the make-root-fs-readonly step. And/or maybe we create an option to preserve the /mutable partition.

It's not clear to me my the write-credentials-to script was removed. It seems like the (simple) code within it ended up getting duplicated.

Why replace get-archive-server-ip-address with lookup-ip-address? I think we actually need to go more specific than more general: To support Azure File Shares, we apparently need to be able to get the name of the server rather than the IP address.

configure-archive.sh and verify-archive-configuration.sh probably belong under setup instead of run. The introduced notion of archive_module seems like it might be
calcifying a bad layout.

I'm not sure we need argument parsing, at this point. I'm arguing that we can skip upgrade, for now, and there don't seem to be any calls to debug().

I welcome further discussion on these points.

> I'd like there to be one entry-point script for manual setup rather than two. I'd like for verification of parameters and reachability of archives to be checked as early as possible, preferably before any persistent changes to the Pi are made. (I'm flexible on changes to /tmp since they get blown away with reboot.) I feel pretty strongly that at the end of running setup, we should have a device independent of the archive mechanism and be left with more or less a dumb usb stick. furthermore, the initial setup should not fail unless it is something catastrophic. the fact that setup can abort just because of a misconfigured archive server (e.g. ip address not reachable) does not seem like a good thing. > I'd like to avoid a model in which the configuration can fail midway through the setup process. I believe we are moving closer to this. > I think we can achieve these goals by extracting all verification logic so that it can be separately (but consistently) invoked from setup-teslausb, configure, and even after having written the config file used by the one-step setup but before booting the Pi. Whether we choose to archive, how and where to archive are configurations that should be easily changeable with minimal to no effort and left up to the end user. I think people will want different ways to utilize the videos that are stored. We need to assume that any storage mechanism will never have 100% uptime so failing to connect should not abort installation of base functionality. If my sftp server is down (e.g. because i'm at work and am setting it up for my home network) I don't see why I can't still go through the setup process and get a working USB drive. > Given the nature and significance of the changes that we're still making supporting upgrade seems like it'll be challenging. Even communicating the scope of a simplified > upgrade seems difficult. I vote that we defer tackling upgrade, at least for this PR. Agreed... I started down that route and ended up abandoning it. > Reflashing is pretty quick. Maybe it's just because I'm practiced, but it takes me just a few minutes to reflash and set up a Pi from scratch. If the idea is that we want to enable people to apply customizations after the install process maybe we can make that explicitly an option. Maybe we make setup-teslausb call a "/boot/customize-setup.sh" if one exists before the make-root-fs-readonly step. And/or maybe we create an option to preserve the /mutable partition. Maybe it's quick now but it'll get annoying once you get some customization in there. You probably don't back up to Google Drive but if you did you'd see that rclone takes several minutes just to install. And what if you have some music on there? Seems odd that you have to copy over all your music files again just because we want to reconfigure. > It's not clear to me my the write-credentials-to script was removed. It seems like the (simple) code within it ended up getting duplicated. That's a fair point. The simple answer is because only the CIFS archive had that mechanism. I believe as a principle we should have all archive have the same interface. If we add it back, we should add it back for all archive mechanisms. > Why replace get-archive-server-ip-address with lookup-ip-address? I think we actually need to go more specific than more general: To support Azure File Shares, we apparently need to be able to get the name of the server rather than the IP address. I don't think having a script return an IP address of a single global variable (`$archiveserver`) is very useful. What happens when there are multiple archive servers and we want the addresses of both of them? Or if we need the IP address of another server down the road, I don't think we should keep making bash scripts for that purpose. If you need to use the server rather than the IP address you can just not use the lookup. I believe the original implementation actually converts the name into and ip address before writing it to a config file -- this is probably likely to cause issues with cloud hosted solutions with dynamic IP addresses. ``` echo "//$archive_server_ip_address/$sharename $archive_path cifs vers=${cifs_version},credentials=${credentials_file_path},iocharset=utf8,file_mode=0777,dir_mode=0777 0" >> /etc/fstab ``` > configure-archive.sh and verify-archive-configuration.sh probably belong under setup instead of run. The introduced notion of archive_module seems like it might be > calcifying a bad layout. I think I covered why configure and verify-archive should be split from set up above. re: archive_module - admittedly i'm not a huge fan of this concept either. i actually think we should define a set of interfaces (bash functions?) that all modules should support in a single file. we instead landed in a place where each interface for each type is in a file -- probably because this is done in bash over an object oriented language. > I'm not sure we need argument parsing, at this point. I'm arguing that we can skip upgrade, for now, and there don't seem to be any calls to debug(). yea, it seems lame right now, i know. i have grander visions for configure to allow you to add/remove configurations, features, etc. for that command lines will be useful to turn on/off certain features -- i'm happy to leave it out. debug is used in a few places in configure but i understand it seems a little useless at this time. > I welcome further discussion on these points. Thanks for sharing your thoughts -- happy to do what's best for the project.

It seems reasonable to have three entry-points for manual setup on the Pi:
1. A "partition" script
2. A "configure archiving" script
3. A user-friendly wrapper for the other two

Verification of the reachability of the archive was added in response to actual reported failures, and those failures were particularly mystifying because they happened when there was no opportunity to present the user with the problem. So, defaulting to performing validation of the configuration of the archive by actually attempting to connect to it seems warranted. Having said that, supporting scenarios in which the Pi is being set up away from the network by someone confident in their ability to properly escape passwords seems reasonable. I imagine a "SKIP_ARCHIVE_VERIFICATION" setting or some such could be one way of supporting this scenario.

I'm not convinced that we'll be able to support reconfiguration of the archive system, in general, but I'm not confident that we won't, either. You make good points about the tedium of re-applying customization, even if I suspect that most people won't bother to even change the password. Having said that, I think of the difference between the "run" and "setup" directories in the repo as being that the "run" stuff is meant to be left on the device whereas the "setup" could generally be cleaned off the device after it was configured. If you want to switch to a different archive system, it's likely that you'll need to be doing some downloading. (E.g. maybe you're switching to Google's new brain-implant file share system, and we didn't support that when you originally set up your Pi.)

Putting all the functions for a single archive system into a single file which could be sourced is an interesting idea. I think there could be some benefit that I'm not thinking of, at the moment. On the other hand, defining the "interface" with a list of file names is actually somewhat clarifying: It's easy to compare the directories and see if anything is missing. (Particularly if we were to adopt a convention of putting ancillary scripts into child directories.) File content is a little noisier to compare.

I'll defer to your judgement on the question of the argument parsing and the debug output. I'm not sure we need different levels of output, but I think reasonable people can disagree on that point.

I've attempted to make a couple of concrete proposals (with some variable degree of precision). I don't mean to ask you or anyone else to implement those proposals; I'll get to them when I can. But if you or anyone else wants to tackle those changes, I welcome you to beat me to it. I expect that I'll have time this weekend.

Please let me know if you think that there are still points to debate; in my mind we've identified a set of changes that will satisfy the goals we've each expressed.

My thoughts, in no particular order. (And @cimryan (and others)  [feel free to join the Slack channel](https://join.slack.com/t/smartusbdrivefortesla/shared_invite/enQtNDY4NDIzMTQ0NjA4LTdlYjFkOGE0Y2NkNjYyZTBiZTNmZTY4OGNhODMwZjg4NGNkZWU3MGY2ZDNhODIzZTAxODhhNzEzNDQ2OTFhMTI)!) 
* You shouldn’t fail base setup unless something’s awfully wrong. Defining "base" as "if you defined nothing or something went wrong you still end up with a usable USB drive and scripts to continue if desired".
* The partition layout should be pretty standardized (a cam store, tmpfs, mutable, and optionally music). This seems like something that can be made to happen regardless of any configuration provided (with CAMPERCENT=100)
* I think calling a post-base configure should be doable based on config being provided or not. It also means a very stable first stage base setup (as above) can be put in the image, which I like. The standard mutable partition would provide scratch space for downloading further scripts based on either manual or automatic input (via config). 
* I think wifi setup has to be pretty standardized too; in all but the rarest cases I would say that wifi will be required. It could be broken out from the main config file, but at a certain point it feels like you're just mimicking the `wpa_supplicant.conf` functionality. That said, for many people, editing (or generating) a single file is quite appealing, and env vars are pretty friendly. So a well baked wifi-enable script (taking config file or prompting) could/should be built into the base image. 
* Anything baked into the image would also have the option of using Python or other, so they could be less brittle than `bash` (not that I'm knocking bash...I just stink at it. :) )

I have a Jenkins server set up for automatic base image builds now. I'll add you to [my pi-gen repo](https://github.com/rtgoodwin/pi-gen) as a collaborator @cimryan. Any branch created as `feature/something` should get built automatically and [available for download](https://docean.hotsawce.com/teslausb_images/). (Note to anyone reading this, these are not necessarily production ready since it's designed for development.)

> It seems reasonable to have three entry-points for manual setup on the Pi:
> 
> 1. A "partition" script
> 2. A "configure archiving" script
> 3. A user-friendly wrapper for the other two

100% on agree with this approach

> 
> Verification of the reachability of the archive was added in response to actual reported failures, and those failures were particularly mystifying because they happened when there was no opportunity to present the user with the problem. So, defaulting to performing validation of the configuration of the archive by actually attempting to connect to it seems warranted. Having said that, supporting scenarios in which the Pi is being set up away from the network by someone confident in their ability to properly escape passwords seems reasonable. I imagine a "SKIP_ARCHIVE_VERIFICATION" setting or some such could be one way of supporting this scenario.

A rechargeable battery solution will not work well for this without some extra piece to shut it down.  You will drain that battery completely, then recharge it a little on your next drive, then discharge it completely again which will not take long since it will not get the longer duration recharge.

There are some good posts about this: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-powerboost-1000c-load-share-usb-charge-boost/overview

Basically this + a LiIon or LiPo which they also sell, and possibly very cheap voltage controller they sell (although the forum suggests the PowerBoost will auto-detect low voltage, and their Lithium batteries have control circuits to prevent overdrain).  So it will power + passthrough charge, switch to battery, back and forth as needed. I haven't ordered it yet but might. 

(I'd be more concerned about a LiPo exploding than a LiIon, though both are rated for very high temps.)

I went with this as a solution, but modified what I connected to the GPIO and did not use a button switch.
https://github.com/NeonHorizon/lipopi

I have it go high enabled when power is supplied via the USB (car turned on). This then boots up the Pi and it begins monitoring for the low power state to plan for a graceful shutdown.

Achieved this on the PowerBoost board by connecting the USB pin to the EN pin. Also connected to the EN pin is the Pi GPIO through a 10K resistor (as shown in lipopi above) and 100K resistor to GND (as shown in lipopi above) to flip it to off when the other two no longer give a high signal. The LB on the PowerBoost board is connected to the Pi GPIO as shown in the demo above.

Only thing I need to do to improve it is to change the cron script to trigger a graceful shutdown on two conditions: either low battery or file transfers all done.

And agree, the way files are written is a mess. (Or, to be more charitable to what is a "free" feature, it is "unoptimized".)

The problem here is that the Tesla cuts the power to the drive before completes writing to the drive. So, the data beyond that 2K is just lost, and the file is actually just 2K in size.

The Tesla won't start writing to a file that was previously written to, that time has already passed.

So, copying the file instead of moving it would just copy a corrupt file instead of moving one.

There are a couple of things we could try to reduce the corruption:
* Apply the "sync" option to the /backingfiles mountpoint in /etc/fstab
* Periodically issue "sync" commands to the filesystem.

The second options seems like a hack. The first option requires using ext3 for the backingfiles partition, I think, since it's my understanding that ext4 doesn't support the sync option.
The 2K files were 10 sequential minutes.  But there is no way to confirm that it was the car and not the Pi since the files are deleted.

Just not deleting files is my request, not the 2K aspect.  If there is a minor accident (no ambulance and cars can still drive), I want the maximum chance of not losing files, so a copy instead of a move would be preferred.

I suspect that, whether or not the file is deleted, it will still just be 2K in size.

We know that files aren't deleted until they're fully transferred. You can confirm this by writing a large file into the TeslaCam directory and naming it, say, saved-1.blob. You can watch your network share to see it start to copy. While it's copying, pull the power from the Pi. Then plug the Pi in, again. It'll start copying the file, again, and copy the whole thing to the share, if you let it, overwriting the bad file with the whole good file. If you do the same thing, deleting the partial file from the share before you plug the Pi back in, you'll see the whole file get copied to the share. So, none of the data in the file was removed from the Pi until the whole file was on the share.

The advantage of this move operation over a copy operation is that the system automatically reclaims space. If we copy instead of move, we have to implement some process to free up space.

It looks like we're going to be adding a partition which is read/write on the SD card. We can move the logs to that partition and we can record the file sizes of the files before they're moved. If we find that the file sizes are different from what we're seeing transferred then we'll know that we're not getting the data. If the file sizes are the same, though, we'll know that copying instead of moving won't provide a benefit.

In the mean time, if you'd like to try running with copy instead of move, you can edit /root/bin/archive-clips.sh and replace the mv command with a cp command.

The `touch /tmp/archive_is_unreachable` tricks the system into thinking that the Pi has driven away from the house. It then immediately detects that the archive server is reachable, and so decides to immediately attempt another archive.

@ken830 I'd look at a tutorial, but basically the steps (for a simple change done via the browser)  are:
1) Fork the repo (upper right corner button). Then make sure you're in your fork, not cimyran/teslausb
2) Find the file you want to edit
3) Edit it with the pencil (if you're comfortable doing all the changes in the browser, else copy it out to your editor, then paste it back)
4) When it asks to save at the bottom, choose "a new branch" (call it whatever you want) and add comments.
5) Come back to this project and you'll see a new button/message appear suggesting you open a PR for your fork+branch to this project `master` branch.  Do so. 

If you want to learn about using the cmd line or maybe you already know, go for: https://codeburst.io/a-step-by-step-guide-to-making-your-first-github-contribution-5302260a2940

The Github for (your OS) Desktop app is pretty useful too, though there are tons. It manages the clone/branch/push process for you but you still edit outside of it. 

The process is pretty much the same every time, and, as a relative newb myself, I find even little things are appreciated. :)

Can you give an example of how making setup-teslausb accept command line parameters would be beneficial?

Being a PowerShell script, setup-piForHeadlessConfig.ps1 already accepts command line parameters and prompts for them if they weren't entered.

When I was working on the previous problem, it would have been really nice if I could have just setup a single command line like
setup-piForHeadlessConfig.ps1 e myssid mykey myserver myfolder myuser mypass mysplit
then have it run through the PowerShell which would hopefully even setup a runonce so that the setup-teslausb starts automatically upon booting the Zero and it could reboot at the end.  After running the PowerShell all you do is move the SD card to the Zero and plug it in and let it go and it should finish.

Experiments are currently underway to evaluate the feasibility of a single-step process: https://github.com/cimryan/teslausb/issues/39

The official image for the Pi lacks a run-once system, and the work involved in creating and maintaining a new image is significant.

Until someone adds the support you're describing (and please feel encouraged to submit a pull request, yourself), the PowerShell script current supports command-line parameters, directly, and setup-teslausb can be invoked from a script, like this:
```
#!/bin/bash
export archiveserver=foo
. . .
setup-teslausb
```

Yes in my current method, I use a .conf file, so all I have to do is copy it back to the SD and run the script. :) 

I'm moving down the path of trying to make the image completely bootable with nothing but a .conf file edit. The tricky bit that I'm poking at is getting the wifi setup with this method w/o any additional edits. We could always just say "make the wpa_supplicant.conf file yourself", but I do like the cleanlinless of only needing one file for all of setup. :)

~New version to test (10-24 image):~ Outdated, see #39 

~Give this [flashable image](https://www.dropbox.com/s/6f8kxenvtz8pkj9/image_2018-10-24-teslausb_headless-lite.zip?dl=0) a try.  (Be sure to click the `...` if needed on Dropbox and download the `.zip` file.)~
Write to card, reinsert it into PC so it mounts `boot` folder. Then create in `boot` a file called `teslausb_setup_variables.conf` and put the vars in it like so (no quotes on any):
```
export archiveserver=your_archive_name_or_ip
export sharename=your_archive_share_name
export shareuser=username
export sharepassword=password
export campercent=100
export SSID=your_ssid
export WIFIPASS=your_pass
```
* Boot it in your Pi, give it a bit, watching for a series of flashes (2, 3, 4, 5, maybe 6) and then a reboot and/or the CAM to become available on your PC/Mac. 
* The Pi should be available at `teslausb.local` over Wifi (if it works) or USB networking (if it doesn't). Takes about 5 minutes for me.  You should see in `boot` the `TESLAUSB_SETUP_FINISHED` and `WIFI_ENABLED` files as markers of success too. 
* I forgot to create the TeslaCam folder, so you'll need to do that before taking to your car. 

LMK if it does/doesn't work for you please, feedback needed! :) Worked great just now; I've only tried it with campercent=100.

I have the same AP and no issues. It sounds like the headless setup script maybe didn't complete the wpa_supplicant.conf file? It should end up looking like this before you reboot:

```
ctrl_interface=DIR=/var/run/wpa_supplicant GROUP=netdev
update_config=1

network={
  ssid="your_ssid"
  psk="your_wifipass"
  key_mgmt=WPA-PSK
}
```
I think you should be able to put the SD card back into your computer to doublecheck/recreate.

Yes. Exactly the same:

```
ctrl_interface=DIR=/var/run/wpa_supplicant GROUP=netdev
update_config=1

network={
  ssid="<MY-SSID>"
  psk="<MY-WIFI-PW>"
  key_mgmt=WPA-PSK
}
```

In that vein, is it really needed to unmount the USB share to archive? (And thus the checks for it to be reachable etc.) The original Reddit post did it ti

I know you don't want R/W going on at the same time on the partition but the same files wouldn't be being modified (since saved files by default are already written out). And since the cam using rolling date and times in the filename, the presence or removal of files shouldn't affect anything while keeping the drive alive. 

@cimryan and others, thoughts on this? Certainly would make a flashable image easier to use and test if we could just note the archive wasn't reachable but the USB share functionality stayed solid. My tentative thinking is to dumb it down to always mount and if the loop tries to archive and it isn't reachable, touch a file `ARCHIVE_UNREACHABLE` in the CAM folder.

I see two potentially separable proposals:
1. Leave the g_mass_storage module loaded at all times.
1. Leave the backing file mounted at all times.

Have you determined that the cause of the camera icon disappearing is the unloading of the g_mass_storage module?

Fundamentally my concern with accessing the backing file through two different file system layers simultaneously is that it's unsupported, and the problem with taking a dependency on unsupported behavior, even if you test it thoroughly, is that you never know what sort of environmental change may cause a break.

Concretely, in my limited experience, changes written through the g_mass_storage interface don't show up with predictability until the backing file is umounted and remounted.

In this case it seems that a loss of connectivity to the archive server caused the script to switch out of the "waiting for archive to be unreachable" state. It's actually switching out of the "waiting for archive to be reachable" state that's more interesting, I think, because it's after leaving that state that the drives will be dismounted. That transition would occur when the Pi thinks it's able to connect to the archive server, which seems unlikely to occur when the Pi is out driving around.

Write to card, reinsert it into PC so it mounts `boot` folder. Then create in `boot` a file called `teslausb_setup_variables.conf` and put the vars in it like so (no quotes on any):
```
export archiveserver=your_archive_name_or_ip
export sharename=your_archive_share_name
export shareuser=username
export sharepassword=password
export campercent=100
export SSID=your_ssid
export WIFIPASS=your_pass
```
* Boot it in your Pi, give it a bit, watching for a series of flashes (2, 3, 4, 5, maybe 6) and then a reboot and/or the CAM to become available on your PC/Mac. 
* The Pi should be available at `teslausb.local` over Wifi (if it works) or USB networking (if it doesn't). Takes about 5 minutes for me.  You should see in `boot` the `TESLAUSB_SETUP_FINISHED` and `WIFI_ENABLED` files as markers of success too. 
* I forgot to create the TeslaCam folder, so you'll need to do that before taking to your car. 

LMK if it does/doesn't work for you please, feedback needed! :) Worked great just now; I've only tried it with campercent=100.

@firedfly 

* Currently I pre-download the scripts before cooking the image, to minimize the chances of failure in a headless setup, and to ensure upstream changes haven't borked something. :) 

I may make that an option at some point when the setup script (or my version of it for headless) is stable enough to trust that the scripts can download and be re-run and not repeat steps, etc. For example, when rsync/SFTP gets merged in, I'll want to ensure that the "headless" version of that setup can be created and not break any current options/combinations. The loop and archive scripts could probably be downloaded automatically since they're quite self-contained. Anyway, all this can/could change if we can move to a "headless-ready" main setup script/process.  

I'd also be happy to add (back) the option to copy scripts from `/boot/somedir` if you/user want to put your own there. The [headless prep script](https://github.com/rtgoodwin/teslausb/blob/headless-patch/headless-scripts/setup-piForHeadlessBuild.sh) did that before: download and put them in the `boot` dir to copy over during setup, but I moved to just downloading them and refreshing the image for stability, and TBH the experience of a single `.conf` file is pretty compelling to me. :)  The prep script is still there for me to refer to if needed or for another purpose if desired. 

Overall, I want to minimize any chance that it doesn't come up with networking configured and ready to troubleshoot, but also have it tightly looped to do its best to do setup if not already completed. 

* The image will still take a wpa_supplicant file if present. 

It's set to check:

1) "did the user pass in `SSID/WIFIPASS`?". 
2) "is there a `/boot/WIFI_ENABLED` file? If not, maybe the user still needs to setup wifi
3) if both are met, removes the wpa_supplicant file with one with the new info and reboots 

This is checked on every boot in case you goof or change network details. If the conditions aren't met, the image takes its normal path to suck in the wpa_supplicant.conf file from /boot. 

I think that kind of gives the best of both worlds...simple for simple setups, and anyone advanced enough to need two networks can create the wpa_supplicant file.

Flash the image, and put `teslausb_setup_variables.conf` in the `boot` dir:
```
export archiveserver=your_archive_name_or_ip
export sharename=your_archive_share_name
export shareuser=username
export sharepassword=password
export campercent=100
export SSID=your_ssid
export WIFIPASS=your_pass
export HEADLESS_SETUP=true
export REPO=rtgoodwin
export BRANCH=headless-patch
``` 
(setup to track my branch for testing since it has the changes to the main setup file)

Pop in Pi Z W and boot!

You can always ssh in and `tail -f /boot/teslausb-headless-setup.log` for progress. I usually wait until I can ping it over wifi, but to each their own. 

Notes (background, not needed for setup):

* It does the bare minimum it needs to setup wifi, then grab and start executing the main script with the variables above. Even if it fails, or you didn't provide the conf file, it's still a ready bootable image for Pi Zero W with USB networking enabled and available at `teslausb.local`
* If HEADLESS_SETUP=true, then the setup script is run in headless mode. I think I might change the first boot procedure to check for this to be "true" overall, instead of just looking for TESLAUSB_SETUP_FINISHED, so the image is useful for either headless or regular setup. 
* I have only tested with CIFS so far though I don't think rsync should fail. 
* It's set to use the new variable to determine whether to flash LEDs for progress
* For reasons unknown to me, `wget` is reaaaaally slow on my setup or sometimes hangs. Using curl for now in the setup script. They should be functionally equal in this usage, and it's much faster. 
* If it doesn't finish (return to flashing LED normally after a few minutes and CAM mounts), you can always ssh in and run /etc/rc.local and both scripts seem to be solid enough to re-run safely. Just give it some time to finish. :) 
* Need to still export the `setup_progress` function down into the ancillary scripts just for visibility. 
* I need to start putting the images somewhere other than Dropbox too when solid. I think it's in great shape now, but some nice touches as mentioned above are probably useful. 

LED flashes to setup stage mapping (although sometimes it's not perfect? LMK):
2 = verify variables
3 = grab scripts
4 = create backing partition/files
5 = done and remount/reboot

@firedfly @cimryan for testing. :) (And whoever else!)

(and pi-gen changes are [here](https://github.com/rtgoodwin/pi-gen/tree/teslausb-headless-image/stage7/00-teslausb-tweaks) )

@rtgoodwin - I did a fresh configuration on an SD card from Windows.  After running `setup-teslausb` and rebooting, the `Cam` drive shows up inside of Windows.

Here are the results of `mount -a -v`.  Ignore the `bad UNC` error--my archive share isn't available:
> root@teslausb:~# mount -a -v
> /proc                    : already mounted
> /boot                    : already mounted
> /                        : ignored
> /backingfiles            : already mounted
> /mnt/cam                 : ignored
> mount.cifs: bad UNC (///TeslaCam)
> /var/log                 : already mounted
> /var/tmp                 : already mounted
> /tmp                     : already mounted

Interesting, I guess `/mnt/cam` is ok to be ignored. So I don't know how to further troubleshoot here, may have to do some googling. Tested on another Mac, different OS level, and it's still not showing up as a USB disk. 

Edit: Ok now I know that "ignored" is due to "noauto". Live and learn.

This line did the trick: `modprobe g_mass_storage file=/backingfiles/cam_disk.bin stall=0`. Immediately the drive showed up. Not sure why that isn't being needed for others, unless Windows maybe triggers something to happen with the USB negotiation. It also doesn't exactly work since I think it's mounting the file directly and not the `/mnt/cam` share (tested by writing files from host and Pi and they aren't in sync). More research in progress.

I'm officially (in this case) an idiot. All my testing is in a scenario where the ARCHIVESERVER is always reachable. So, of course the drive gets unmounted from my Mac. (Facepalm) At least that seems to be the scenario. 

@firedfly in your testing were they showing up if your laptop+Pi were on the same network as your ARCHIVESERVER? 

@cimryan am I totally misreading the mount logic? The original script loaded `g_mass_storage` in rc.local, presumably for this reason, and then had slightly different logic as to when to disconnect. 

So, and again I could be really off on this whole thing, this makes this really a dev problem, or if someone wants to inspect the USB share on their machine while the Pi is on the network.  (The latter being a pretty reasonable case, actually. In fact, the instructions currently have you create the TeslaCam folder that way, and/or copy music.)

Could always just leave it mounted, but R/W access from both sides is a Bad Thing(tm), so looking for compromises. I'm not sure how to get around that. 

I suppose you could:

-  remount the USB share `ro` once the archive is reachable. Then at least someone could manually copy off files using their PC if the archive process was just not super successful/consistent. If it's plugged into the car, Tesla _should_ detect it dis/appearing, see it's not writeable, and that'd probably be fine since you likely don't want footage of the inside (or outside) of your garage/parking structure. The downside would be if Tesla does release a method to provide constant power to both dashcam AND the USB ports, but that seems unlikely for the moment. 

- Then update the copy process to test presence of the target `saved-` file and if it `exists && is same size (or date?)` then don't copy, just delete it from the `rw` `/mnt/cam`. This is to cover "I brought the Pi inside, and copied a ton of data off of it, then put it back in the car". (Since deleting files wouldn't be allowed in `ro`.) 

Thoughts? This probably ends up getting closed and a new issue opened to allow for this scenario if we want it. It seems like it has value. Or it's an actual bug/timing issue.

The archive-teslacam-clips script starts with disconnecting the drives from the usb host and ends with connecting them. So, the drives should only be missing from the host while clips are being copied.

However, the script is run with -eu, so if anything goes wrong the whole thing exits. I suspect that you're not seeing the drives get remounted because something is going wrong during an execution of archive-teslacam-clips, and so execution isn't reaching the last line, which reloads g_mass_storage.

Do you see "Connected usb to host." in /tmp/archive-teslacam-clips.log?

You nailed it. Stray typo in the local file was causing it to silently exit. Time to wipe and re-setup from master anyway. The good news is I now have remembered a small fraction of the large amount of filesystem knowledge I forgot.

Thanks for reporting this experience, firedfly.

I also noticed that the update was very slow, this evening. I was seeing download rates as low as 5kb/s. The process was much faster yesterday, so I'm not sure if this will be a continuing pain point or not.

I'm also not sure of what the potential implications of skipping this step are, or how we might skip some of the data.

Until someone does some research to demonstrate that it's safe to skip this step, or to identify a faster way of achieving the same result, or we identify that this is a continuing problem that we can't tolerate, I'm not inclined to disable the update.

Let's keep this issue open while we gather data.

It took about 3-4 minutes for me. The Pi has the bandwidth, but sometimes it's...unstable. I've seen `wget` hang for a good minute or so occasionally. Which jogs my mind about adding some stats to the copy procedure to see just how fast things are getting xferred and set user expectations.

The slowness on updating the package index doesn't appear to be common.  I've re-configured a pi a few times and updating of the index runs in an acceptable time.

I looked into the script used as a starting point for `make-root-fs-readonly.sh`.  Based on commit history several packages are removed as they will not work with a read-only file system.  In a few instances, replacement packages are installed.

Based on this information, it seems advisable to keep the script as is.

Yes, it's possible. To make this change find the following line in archive-teslacam-clips:
```
for file_name in "$CAM_MOUNT"/TeslaCam/saved*; do
```
Change it to
```
for file_name in "$CAM_MOUNT"/TeslaCam/*; do
```
We probably won't make this the default behavior. See the discussion in this issue for the reasoning: https://github.com/cimryan/teslausb/issues/5

You can already achieve this, with an important caveat:
Multiple networks can be specified while editing the wpa_supplicant.conf file by creating multiple network blocks.
However, this guide currently leaves the Pi insecure: SSH enabled with a default password. That's OK as long as you're only connecting to networks that you control, but connecting to a shared network means that the Pi could get exploited. So, if we add instructions for how to connect to multiple networks we should also add instructions for how to lock down SSH on the Pi.

Seems like Google has [pretty good documentation on the how-to](https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/resumable-upload), but there's a main caveat: to use an access token, you'll need to generate it utilizing their OAuth 2.0 implementation. This deals with a client ID **and more importantly a client secret**, which means it'll need to be obfuscated somehow if it'll be bundled with the pi.

Is using Python for this a little too far fetched for the project? Seems simple enough to be able to do it from command line but having a script that helps with oauth token refreshes will be immensely helpful, and [they have a nice SDK for Python](https://developers.google.com/api-client-library/python/guide/aaa_oauth) as well.

Let's use each language in its appropriate place. Bash is good for launching scripts and programs and operating on files, but is lousy for complex logic. Python is complementary. IMHO.

So, I think the tactical application of Python would likely be appropriate.

I'm currently hitting a few snags with my implementation. I'm using `campercent=100` on a 64GB card, and it creates a ~53GB CAM mount just fine. I can put a TeslaCam folder on it and put files in that folder on Windows, but now the problem comes from reading that drive on the teslausb pi. For some reason, the `/mnt/cam/` folder is empty, despite having the `TeslaCam` folder (and files in it) that persists through ejecting and plugging back in the teslausb pi. Is my script looking at the wrong spot? I know the traditional method is to move the files over from the cam mount to the archive mount, which is mounted to a shared drive. But that isn't needed for rsync, since it can just copy directly from the cam mount folder.

I also notice that Windows pops up with this when the teslausb pi first boots and connects to my PC:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5162166/47262163-131f8c00-d4af-11e8-8417-cc1c57576e96.png)


Another issue is that it also keeps disconnecting even though the archive server is reachable. Individual, repeated calls to `ping` to the ftp/rsync server return the packet just fine, so for some reason it can't reach it, unmounts the USB, remounts the USB, and tries to archive again. It's bizarre.

So I did some further digging and was able to figure out the first issue! It was due to the connection to the ftp server requiring accepting the authenticity of the FTP server's host key (needed to type 'yes'), so I'll be updating the instructions to help ensure people don't have this bizarre issue.

The other two issues remain though, and other than the weird disconnection issue causing the teslausb pi to just spam my computer as if I was plugging in and out a USB drive every 5-20 seconds, it should be ready for merge.

ping -q -w 1 -c 1 "$ARCHIVE_HOST_NAME" > /tmp/ping.log 2>&1 || reachable=false

Network name is set to "teslausb".

I've split out the suggestions into separate issues so that they can be tackled one by one.

My read of the initial scripts was that they were intended to just copy the clips that one had elected to save. Do you think that intention should be reconsidered? If so, I'd like to hear more about these "recent-" files so we can decide whether to always copy them or to somehow make that a configurable option.

Copied from previous Reddit post: *The filename format for saved clips is (example) saved-front-2018-10-08_09-00.mp4 (so saved-camera-year-month-day_hour-minute.mp4)* *Edit: looks like the rolling buffer is recent-front-year-month-day_hour(24 hour fmt)_segment, where segment appears to be each minute for the last hour, and the minute segments get rolled off as the hour rounds. So you have (example) `recent-front-2018-10-09_17-56.mp4`, `57`, `58`, `59`, then it rolls to `18-00.mp4` and so on.* *Edit2: Ok I'm still not 100% sure on the specs there, but there are at least those kinds of files, and also what seems to be a lock file (buffer) in the root. I guess all things considered, you could do worse than just copying everything off out of the folder. :)* So, not fully determined, but that's my working theory. I.e. if you wanted to preserve rolling buffer, it's a series of one minute clips named as above. And if the car shuts off, it seems to truncate the currently open file, leaving it unusable. See screenshot, with a working 1 minute (30.1mb) file, followed by the next segment which truncated at 14.1mb and doesn't appear to be a valid .mp4. You *might* want to pull this stuff off if you've forgotten to do a manual save from the touch screen. As with all things, probably making it an option makes sense. Either in the config file or in the archive move loop. Especially since there's really not much of a window for getting the clips copied off before the car powers off, and since it can take up to 1 minute for the drive to come online when the car is powered on. You could then choose to optimize for "completeness" (copy all) or "least amount of time sitting in the car before leaving/arriving" (copy saved* only). When I parked earlier, I made a point of getting out of the car slowly, grabbing stuff from the front seat, etc., and still only got a few files copied. Hopefully this makes some sense, it's been a long day. 😄 It's never going to be perfect; but sitting in the car for an extra minute or 2 (or if someone works out a battery solution) is still a lot better than having to shuffle a USB drive back and forth. And way cooler...

I agree that the recent files seem to represent the rolling buffer. Copying those files off would copy the last ten minutes before the car arrived back home. I don't think those last ten minutes are likely to be more interesting than any other files from the drive, so I don't think they're worth copying without a human directing the system to save the video for them.

I'm ok with that. In fact I could even see it go another way and just have the script have an optional loop where it just copies the rolling buffer out to a backup directory. For folks that buy bigger cards to be safe, there is a TON of extra room. So during the archive step, you could just copy the completed recents out to MONTH_DAY folder and boom, less worry about saving. 

Closing this one out, that can be a separate feature request. I want to punch in an optional section to use Pushover to notify your phone when copying is complete. Should just be a few lines (to grab config values and store them, and then a curl call). Just need time... :)
Good luck!
